6-10-8: Crossing Prohibited
6-10-9: Obedience To Railroad Signals
6-10-1: PEDESTRIANS SUBJECT TO TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNALS:
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control signals as provided for in this
title, but at all other places pedestrians shall be granted those rights and be
subject to the restrictions stated in this chapter. (1990 Code § 15-1001)
6-10-2: CROSSWALKS:
   A.   Right Of Way:
      1.   When traffic control signals are not in place or not in operation,
the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way slowing down or stopping,
if need be, to so yield to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk
when:
         a.   The pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the
vehicle is traveling; or
         b.   The pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite edge
of the roadway as to be in danger.
The provisions of this subsection A1 are not applicable under conditions where
pedestrians are required to yield pursuant to this chapter.
      2.   No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety
or walk or run into the path of the vehicle which is so close that it is
impossible for the driver to yield.
      3.   Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk, or any
unmarked crosswalk, or at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross a
roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not
overtake to pass such stopped vehicle. (1990 Code § 15-1002)
   B.   Use Right Half Of Crosswalk: Pedestrians, when crossing the street at a
crosswalk, shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of the
crosswalk. (1990 Code § 15-1003)
6-10-3: CROSSING AT RIGHT ANGLES:
No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right
angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb, except in a
crosswalk. (1990 Code § 15-1004)
6-10-4: YIELD BY PEDESTRIANS:
   A.   Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a
marked or unmarked crosswalk at any intersection shall yield the right of way
to all vehicles upon the roadway.
   B.   Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel
or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right of way
to all vehicles upon the roadway.
   C.   The provisions of this section are not applicable where pedestrian
crossings are prohibited. (1990 Code § 15-1005)
6-10-5: WALKING ALONG ROADWAYS:
   A.   Where sidewalks are provided, it is unlawful for any pedestrian to walk
along and upon an adjacent roadway.
   B.   Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon
a highway shall, when practical, walk only on the left side of the roadway, or
its shoulder, facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction,
and shall yield to approaching vehicles. (1990 Code § 15-1006)
6-10-6: SOLICITING FROM VEHICLE OCCUPANTS:
No person shall:
   A.   Stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride, donations,
employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle.
   B.   Stand in any street or roadway, or park and stop or attempt to stop and
engage any person in any vehicle for the purpose of soliciting contributions or
the watching or guarding of any vehicle while parked or about to be parked on a
street.
   C.   Sell or attempt to sell anything to any person in any vehicle.
   D.   Hand or attempt to hand to any person in any vehicle any circular,
advertisement, handbill or any political campaign literature, or any sample,
souvenir or gift.
   E.   In any other manner, while standing in the street or roadway, attempt
to interfere with the normal flow of traffic for any other similar purpose.
(1990 Code § 15-1007)
6-10-7: DRIVERS EXERCISE DUE CARE:
Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this chapter, every driver shall
exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway, and
shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise
proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated
person on the roadway. (1990 Code § 15-1008)
6-10-8: CROSSING PROHIBITED:
Between adjacent intersections, at which traffic control signals are in
operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk.
Pedestrians shall not cross any divided highway having a median in the center
thereof, except in a crosswalk. (1990 Code § 15-1009)
6-10-9: OBEDIENCE TO RAILROAD SIGNALS:
No pedestrian shall pass through, around, over, or under any crossing gate or
barrier at a railroad grade crossing while such gate or barrier is closed or is
being opened or closed. (1990 Code § 15-1010)
CHAPTER 11
BICYCLES; MOTORCYCLES; MOTOR SCOOTERS
SECTION:
6-11-1: Application Of Provisions
6-11-2: Obedience To Traffic Control Devices
6-11-3: Riding On Bicycles
6-11-4: Riding On Roadways And Bicycle Paths
6-11-5: Speed Of Bicycle
6-11-6: Emerging From Alley Or Driveway
6-11-7: Carrying Articles
6-11-8: Parking
6-11-9: Riding On Sidewalks
6-11-10: Lamps And Equipment On Bicycles
6-11-11: Use Limits On Motorcycles, Motor Scooters, Bicycles
6-11-12: Motorcycle Equipment; Headgear
6-11-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Bicycle Regulations: The provisions of this chapter
shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or upon any public
way; or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to
those exceptions stated in this chapter. (1990 Code § 15-1101)
   B.   Application Of Traffic Laws To Bicycles: Every person riding a bicycle
upon a roadway shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the
duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this state and the
traffic provisions of this code applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except
as to special regulations in this chapter, except as to those provisions of
laws and ordinances which by their nature are inapplicable to such persons.
(1990 Code § 15-1102)
6-11-2: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
   A.   Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official
traffic control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to vehicles
unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
   B.   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating no right or left or U-
turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the directions
of such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make any
such turn, in which event, such person shall then obey the regulations
applicable to the pedestrians. (1990 Code § 15-1103)
6-11-3: RIDING ON BICYCLES:
   A.   Ride Upon Seat: No person operating a bicycle shall ride other than
astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto.
   B.   Carrying Passengers: No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at
one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. (1990 Code §
15-1104)
6-11-4: RIDING ON ROADWAYS AND BICYCLE PATHS:
   A.   Riding To Right Side Of Roadway: Every person operating a bicycle upon
a roadway shall ride as near to the right hand side of the roadway as
practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or a vehicle
proceeding in the same direction.
   B.   Riding Two Abreast: Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not
ride more than two (2) abreast, except on paths or parts of roadways set aside
for the exclusive use of bicycles.
   C.   Use Of Bicycle Paths: If usable paths for bicycles are provided
adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such paths and shall not use
the roadway. (1990 Code § 15-1105)
6-11-5: SPEED OF BICYCLE:
No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and
prudent under the conditions then existing. (1990 Code § 15-1106)
6-11-6: EMERGING FROM ALLEY OR DRIVEWAY:
The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley or driveway shall, upon
approaching a sidewalk or sidewalk area extending across the alley or driveway,
yield the right of way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or
sidewalk area. Upon entering the roadway, the bicycle operator shall yield the
right of way to all vehicles approaching on the roadways. (1990 Code § 15-1107)
6-11-7: CARRYING ARTICLES:
No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle, or article which
prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand on the handlebars. (1990 Code
§ 15-1108)
6-11-8: PARKING:
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway
against the curb, or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle, or
against the building or at the curb in such a manner as to afford the least
obstruction to pedestrian traffic. (1990 Code § 15-1109)
6-11-9: RIDING ON SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Business District: No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk
within a business district.
   B.   Council Authority To Prohibit: The city council, by motion or
resolution, is authorized to have erected signs on any sidewalk or roadway
prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon by any person; and when such signs
are in place, no person shall disobey the same.
   C.   Yield To Pedestrians: Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a
sidewalk, such person shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian and shall
give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. (1990 Code §
15-1110)
6-11-10: LAMPS AND EQUIPMENT ON BICYCLES:
   A.   Lights Or Reflectors: Bicycles in use at night shall be equipped with a
lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at
least five hundred feet (500') to the front and with a red reflector on the
rear of a type which shall be visible from fifty feet (50') to three hundred
feet (300') to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of
headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a
distance of five hundred feet (500') to the rear may be used in addition to the
red reflector.
   B.   Siren, Whistle Prohibited: A bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor
shall any person use, any siren or whistle.
   C.   Brake: Bicycles shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the
operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. (1990
Code § 15-1111; amd. 2004 Code)
6-11-11: USE LIMITS ON MOTORCYCLES, MOTOR SCOOTERS, BICYCLES:
   A.   Carrying Passengers: No driver of a two (2) wheel or three (3) wheel
motor vehicle or bicycle shall carry any other person upon or within such
vehicle on any street or highway, except as provided in this section:
      1.   If any two (2) wheel or three (3) wheel motor vehicle with a wheel
diameter of twelve inches (12") or greater or any bicycle shall have either a
double seating device with double foot rests or a side car attachment providing
a separate seat space within such sidecar attachment for each person riding
therein so that such person shall be seated entirely within the body of the
side car, then it shall be permissible for an operator who has attained the age
of sixteen (16) or older to carry a passenger; and
      2.   A demonstration ride by a licensed dealer or his employee is
permissible.
   B.   Motorcycles And Motor Scooters Prohibited On Sidewalks: No motorcycle
or motor scooter shall be ridden upon any sidewalk of the city.
   C.   Attaching To Moving Vehicles: No rider of a motorcycle, bicycle, or
motor scooter shall hold onto any moving vehicle for the purpose of being
propelled.
   D.   Riding On Seat: A person operating a motor scooter, motorcycle, motor
driven cycle, or motor bicycle, shall ride only on the permanent and regular
seat attached thereto.
   E.   Passing Vehicles Between Lanes Of Traffic: No driver of a motorcycle or
motor scooter shall pass other vehicles in between lanes of traffic traveling
in the same direction. Authorized emergency vehicles are excepted from the
provisions of this subsection.
   F.   Hours Restricted; Underage Persons: No person under the age of sixteen
(16) shall operate any motorcycle, motor bicycle, or motor scooter within the
city between and during the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. of one day and
four o'clock (4:00) A.M. of the next day. (1990 Code § 15-518)
6-11-12: MOTORCYCLE EQUIPMENT; HEADGEAR:
   A.   Required Equipment: In addition to all other requirements, motorcycles
and motor scooters shall be equipped with the following:
      1.   Handlebars which do not exceed twelve inches (12") in height,
measured from the crown or point of attachment.
      2.   Two (2) mirrors, containing a reflection surface of not less than
three inches (3") in diameter, mounted one on each side of the vehicle and
positioned so as to enable the operator to clearly view the roadway for a
distance of two hundred feet (200') to the rear of his vehicle.
      3.   Brakes adequate to control the movement of the vehicle, to stop and
hold the vehicle, including two (2) separate means of applying the brakes. One
means for applying the brakes shall be to effectively apply the brakes to the
front wheel, and one means shall be to effectively apply the brakes to the rear
wheels. All such vehicles shall be equipped with a stop lamp on the rear of the
vehicle which shall display a red or amber light, or any shade of color between
red and amber, visible from a distance of not less than one hundred feet (100')
to the rear in normal sunlight, and which shall be activated upon application
of the service brake.
      4.   A properly operating speedometer capable of registering at least the
maximum legal speed limit for that vehicle shall be provided.
      5.   A fender over each wheel. All fenders shall be of the type provided
by the manufacturer.
      6.   One lighted headlamp capable of showing a white light visible at
least three hundred feet (300') in the direction in which the vehicle is
proceeding, and one tail lamp mounted on the rear which, when lighted, shall
emit a red light plainly visible from at least three hundred feet (300') to the
rear. The lights required by this subsection shall be burning whenever the
vehicle is in motion during the period from one-half (1/2) hour after sunset to
one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise and at any other time when, due to
insufficient light or unfavorable atmospheric conditions, persons and vehicles
on the streets are not clearly discernible at a distance of at least five
hundred feet (500') ahead.
      7.   A windshield of sufficient quality, size and thickness to protect
the operator from foreign objects. In lieu of the windshield, the operator
shall wear goggles or face shield of material and design to protect him from
foreign objects. (1990 Code § 15-519)
   B.   Headgear: No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall operate or
ride upon any vehicle covered under this section unless the person is equipped
with and wearing on the head a crash helmet of a type which complies with
standards established by 59 CFR section 571.218. All such helmets shall consist
of lining, padding and chin straps and be of the type as not to distort the
view of the driver. (1990 Code § 15-519; amd. 2004 Code)
   C.   Exhaust System 1 : No person may operate a motorcycle or motor scooter
with the exhaust system modified so that motor noise is increased greater than
that of the original muffler equipment provided by the manufacturers of the
vehicle. (1990 Code § 15-519)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  6-9-4 of this title.
CHAPTER 12
VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT 1
SECTION:
6-12-1: Purpose
6-12-2: Place Of Impoundment
6-12-3: Duration Of Impoundment
6-12-4: Police Authority
6-12-5: Disabled Vehicles
6-12-6: Vehicles On Bridge
6-12-7: Arrest And Detention Of Driver
6-12-8: Traffic Hazard
6-12-9: Illegal Trespass By Vehicle
6-12-10: Overtime Parking
6-12-11: Blocking Fire Exits Or Hydrants
6-12-12: Parking In Intersection
6-12-13: Stolen Vehicles; Recovery By Police
6-12-14: Outstanding Traffic Citations
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 4, chapter 5 of this code.
6-12-1: PURPOSE:
The impoundment of vehicles under authority of the provisions of this chapter
shall be construed as an enforcement procedure for protection of the public
peace, safety and welfare, and the safeguarding of property, and shall be used
generally for the prevention and removal of traffic hazards, prevention and
abatement of public nuisances arising from traffic law violations, protection
of the public rights in the use of streets and thoroughfares from obstructions
placed and left in derogation of those rights, and for safeguarding and
protecting recovered stolen vehicles. (1990 Code § 15-1301)
6-12-2: PLACE OF IMPOUNDMENT:
Every vehicle that is impounded under the provisions of this chapter shall be
removed to the nearest garage or place of safekeeping designated by the city
and to no other place. (1990 Code § 15-1302)
6-12-3: DURATION OF IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Order For Release: Except as otherwise provided, any vehicle impounded
under the authority of this chapter shall be stored and held safely until an
order for its release is received from an officer of the traffic violations
bureau or other proper police officer.
   B.   Payment Of Costs: The order of release of an impounded vehicle shall be
conditioned upon the payment by the person to whom the release is issued of all
impoundment costs and accrued storage charges assessed against the vehicle.
(1990 Code § 15-1303)
6-12-4: POLICE AUTHORITY:
Members of the police department are hereby authorized within the limits set
forth in this chapter to impound vehicles under the circumstances hereinafter
enumerated. No impoundment shall be valid unless made under order of an
authorized police officer and in strict adherence with the procedures required
in this chapter. (1990 Code § 15-1304)
6-12-5: DISABLED VEHICLES:
A disabled vehicle upon a street or highway may be impounded under the
following circumstances:
   A.   If left unattended and improperly parked on a street or highway and
constitutes a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic;
or
   B.   If the person in charge of the vehicle is physically incapacitated to
such extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal and the
vehicle is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic or a hazard.
(1990 Code § 15-1305)
6-12-6: VEHICLES ON BRIDGE:
An unattended vehicle left upon any bridge, viaduct or causeway or in any tube
or underpass, where the vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic or
hazard, may be impounded. (1990 Code § 15-1306; amd. 2004 Code)
6-12-7: ARREST AND DETENTION OF DRIVER:
Whenever the driver or person in charge of any vehicle is placed under arrest
and taken into custody and detained by police under circumstances which leave
or will leave a vehicle unattended on any street or highway, the vehicle may be
impounded, unless the driver or person in charge can provide immediately for
the vehicle's custody or removal. (1990 Code § 15-1307)
6-12-8: TRAFFIC HAZARD:
A vehicle left unattended upon any street, alley or thoroughfare and so parked
illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal
movement of traffic shall be impounded. (1990 Code § 15-1308)
6-12-9: ILLEGAL TRESPASS BY VEHICLE:
   A.   Impoundment Upon Complaint: An unattended vehicle found to be in
violation of this title may be impounded when the required complaint has been
properly made and filed as provided in this section.
   B.   Filing Of Complaint: If a violation of the provisions of this title
occurs, the owner or legal occupant who complains shall sign a complaint
against the person parking the vehicle on the owner's or legal occupant's
property, or if the identity of the person parking the vehicle is unknown, then
the complaint may be filed against the registered owner of the vehicle. The
complaint shall be verified and shall allege that the complaining party is the
owner or legal occupant of the property upon which the vehicle is parked or
standing.
   C.   Police Impoundment: Upon filing of the complaint by the property owner
or legal occupant, and if there appears to be proper cause to believe the
provisions of this title have been violated, the police department shall cause
the vehicle to be impounded from the property and placed in storage. (1990 Code
§ 15-1309)
6-12-10: OVERTIME PARKING:
Any unattended vehicle which has been parked for more than one hour in excess
of the time allowed for parking in any place shall be impounded, and any
vehicle parked in violation of this title, regarding more than forty eight (48)
hours, shall be impounded. (1990 Code § 15-1310)
6-12-11: BLOCKING FIRE EXITS OR HYDRANTS:
Any vehicle illegally parked in such a manner that it blocks a fire escape
ladder, device or exit or blocks ready access to a fire hydrant shall be
impounded. (1990 Code § 15-1311)
6-12-12: PARKING IN INTERSECTION:
Any unattended vehicle illegally parked in any street intersection shall be
impounded. A disabled vehicle in an intersection, with the person in charge of
the vehicle being present, shall be moved out of the intersection and to the
nearest available legal parking space at the street curbing. (1990 Code § 15-
1312)
6-12-13: STOLEN VEHICLES; RECOVERY BY POLICE:
   A.   Removal By Police: Whenever a stolen vehicle is located by police and
the registered owner cannot be found within a reasonable time not exceeding one
hour, or cannot be determined from the registration papers or other identifying
media in the vehicle or from records or information available from reports of
stolen cars, the vehicle may be removed to the nearest authorized place of
impoundment and the registered owner of the vehicle shall be notified of the
location of the place of impoundment as soon as possible by the police
department.
   B.   Owner Responsibility: If the registered owner is identified, located
and notified of the recovery of the stolen vehicle, the owner shall be given
the right to make his own arrangement for the removal of the vehicle within the
period of one hour from the time he is actually notified of its recovery, and
if the owner is unable or unwilling to effect the removal within the time
specified, the vehicle may be impounded. (1990 Code § 15-1313)
6-12-14: OUTSTANDING TRAFFIC CITATIONS:
Any vehicle for which two (2) or more citations have been issued, for violation
of an ordinance, and have not been presented as required, may be impounded if
parked in violation of any provision of this title. (1990 Code § 15-1314)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREET USE AND OBSTRUCTION
SECTION:
7-1-1: Trees And Shrubbery
7-1-2: Obstructing With Merchandise
7-1-3: Interference With Pedestrian And Vehicular Traffic
7-1-4: Playing On Streets
7-1-5: Water From Filling Stations, Other Businesses
7-1-6: Responsibility For Hazardous Conditions
7-1-7: Drainage Obstruction
7-1-8: Injuring; Driving Over Curbing And Crossings
7-1-9: Vehicle Owner Responsible For Damage To Street
7-1-10: Protecting Trees From Insects And Worms
7-1-11: Notice To Clean Sidewalks; Failure To Comply
7-1-12: Penalty
7-1-1: TREES AND SHRUBBERY:
   A.   Trimming Required:
      1.   The owner of any premises abutting on any street of the city shall
trim all trees and shrubbery growing in the parking, between the sidewalks and
the roadway, of any such street, and all trees and shrubbery growing on any
part of the premises adjacent to the sidewalks or any street or alley, in such
manner that the boughs or limbs thereof shall not obstruct free and convenient
passage and travel along the streets, sidewalks, and alleys. When such premises
are occupied by some person other than the owner, such occupant shall trim the
trees and shrubbery in the same manner as hereinafter required of the owner.
Such trees and shrubbery shall be trimmed so that the lowest branches or
foliage shall not be lower than ten feet (10') above the roadway of a street or
alley, nor lower than eight feet (8') above the sidewalk.
      2.   Any owner or occupant who shall fail, refuse or neglect to trim
trees and shrubbery as provided in subsection A of this section, after
receiving five (5) days' notice from the head of the department in charge of
streets to do so, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. Every day
that the owner or occupant shall fail, refuse or neglect to trim the trees or
shrubbery, after the expiration of the five (5) days' notice, shall be a
separate offense. (1990 Code § 14-101)
   B.   Injuring: It is unlawful for any person to injure any tree or shrubbery
on a street or alley in the city; provided, that this shall not prohibit the
lawful and proper care and removal of such trees and shrubbery. (1990 Code §
14-102)
7-1-2: OBSTRUCTING WITH MERCHANDISE:
   A.   Obstruction Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to place upon or permit to be placed upon the sidewalks, parkways,
streets and alleys of the city any goods, wares, articles of merchandise or any
other obstruction, and leave same thereon; or to use the same as a place to
carry on a business or trade, except as provided in subsection B of this
section. (1990 Code § 14-103; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Exception: It is lawful for an owner or occupant of premises abutting
on a sidewalk in the city to store on the sidewalk goods, wares and merchandise
if a space at least six feet (6') in width is left clear for passage of traffic
or pedestrians. Such goods, wares and merchandise may not be stored or
displayed on the sidewalk in such a manner that vehicles parking at the curb
could be damaged thereby. Such goods, wares and merchandise must be removed by
the owner or occupant of the premises at least once during each twenty four
(24) hour period. (1990 Code § 14-112)
7-1-3: INTERFERENCE WITH PEDESTRIAN AND VEHICULAR TRAFFIC:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use or obstruct the
sidewalks of the city in any manner so as to interfere unduly with pedestrian
traffic thereon, or to use or obstruct the streets and alleys of the city in
any manner so as to interfere unduly with lawful traffic and parking thereon.
(1990 Code § 14-104)
7-1-4: PLAYING ON STREETS:
It is unlawful for any person to play on the main traveled portion of the
streets and alleys of the city, except as may be authorized by ordinance. (1990
Code § 14-105)
7-1-5: WATER FROM FILLING STATIONS, OTHER BUSINESSES:
It is unlawful for any owner or operator of a filling station or other place of
business, or any agent or employee thereof, to cause or allow water, grease or
other fluid to flow or drain into, upon, over or across any sidewalk, parking,
street, alley or other public way. (1990 Code § 14-106)
7-1-6: RESPONSIBILITY FOR HAZARDOUS CONDITIONS:
It is unlawful for the owner or occupant of property abutting upon a sidewalk
area to permit the sidewalk or sidewalk area adjacent to the property to become
a hazard to persons using the sidewalk, or sidewalk area. (1990 Code § 14-107)
7-1-7: DRAINAGE OBSTRUCTION:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to obstruct any street,
sidewalk, or alley by placing any approach driveway or other obstruction or
substance whatever that will obstruct or prevent the natural flow of water into
the storm sewers or drains, or dam the same so as to back any water upon the
streets, alleys, sidewalks, or gutter. (1990 Code § 14-109)
7-1-8: INJURING; DRIVING OVER CURBING AND CROSSINGS:
Any person who shall wilfully or wantonly cut, break or remove, or in any
manner displace, any curbing or guttering, or who shall recklessly or
intentionally drive any vehicle loaded with asphalt materials, lumber or
building materials of any kind into or on the curbing or concrete guttering of
any paved street shall be guilty of an offense. (1990 Code § 14-110)
7-1-9: VEHICLE OWNER RESPONSIBLE FOR DAMAGE TO STREET:
The owner, driver, operator or mover of any vehicle over any street or alley of
the city, and specifically vehicles of a load weight in excess of passenger
automobiles and light delivery trucks, shall be responsible for all damages
which streets or alleys may sustain as a result of the use thereof by such
vehicles. This shall not be applicable to deterioration caused by normal
vehicular use of such streets and alleys. The amount of such damage may be
recovered in an action in the court of proper jurisdiction in the name of the
city. (1990 Code § 14-111)
7-1-10: PROTECTING TREES FROM INSECTS AND WORMS:
Each owner, agent, or occupant in front of or on whose lots shade trees have
been planted or are growing shall use every reasonable precaution to protect
the same from insects and worms. (1990 Code § 14-113)
7-1-11: NOTICE TO CLEAN SIDEWALKS; FAILURE TO COMPLY:
If any property owner, occupant or agent of such property shall fail or refuse
to repair or clean off the sidewalk abutting or adjacent to the property owned
or occupied by him within seventy two (72) hours after notice served on him by
any police officer, health officer, or any other agent of the city, the
property owner, occupant or agent so failing or refusing, after notice so to
do, to repair or clean off such sidewalk shall be deemed guilty of an offense.
(1990 Code § 14-108)
7-1-12: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter
shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1990 Code § 14-115)
CHAPTER 2
STREET EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
7-2-1: Permit Required; Fee
7-2-2: Duties Upon Completion Of Work
7-2-3: Protection Of Public
7-2-4: Acceptance, Inspection Of Completed Work
7-2-5: Location Of Excavation Area Required
7-2-5A: Fee Required For Street Excavation
7-2-6: Penalty
7-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   Permit Required: Before beginning any boring, cutting or excavation
under, across or through any street, highway or alley, or in any right of way
or easement adjacent to any street, highway or alley, the party about to
perform the same shall apply for a permit therefore from the City;
   B.   Fee: The fee for the permit shall be set by the City Council. No permit
fee is required from an entity that pays franchise fee(s) to the City of
Poteau. (Ord. 815, 11-7-2022)
7-2-2: DUTIES UPON COMPLETION OF WORK:
After the work is completed, the person making the opening shall fill the bore,
cut or excavation and tamp the earth or other fill material as specified by the
City, subject to the rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the City.
The party making any such bore, cut or excavation shall replace any paving,
whether asphalt, concrete or a combination, damaged, destroyed, or removed in
like manner as existed prior to such bore, cut or excavation. (Ord. 815, 11-7-
2022)
7-2-3: PROTECTION OF PUBLIC:
It is the duty of any person making an excavation in the street, highway or
alley, or in any right of way or easement adjacent to any street, highway or
alley of the city to adequately and sufficiently protect all such excavations
by barricades or other obstructions, including all appropriate warnings about
the excavation so as to prevent accidents or injury to persons or property
until such time as such excavation is resurfaced and approved by the City.
(Ord. 815, 11-7-2022)
7-2-4: ACCEPTANCE, INSPECTION OF COMPLETED WORK:
The requirements for the work allowed pursuant to the permit shall not be
considered to have been complied with until the City shall have accepted the
street, highway or alley, or any right of way or easement adjacent to any
street, highway or alley as being in good condition. In the event that the
person making the opening shall fail to leave the street, highway or alley, or
any right of way or easement adjacent to any street, highway or alley, in a
good state of repair, satisfactory to the City, thence the City shall call upon
the person making the opening to pay for the cost of repairing such street,
highway or alley, or any right of way or easement adjacent to any street,
highway or alley. In the event the person making the opening fails to repair
such street, highway or alley, or any right of way or easement adjacent to any
street, highway or alley, the city may proceed to have the street, highway or
alley, or any right of way or easement adjacent to any street, highway or
alley, put in good condition, and may pursue all legal remedies available to
the city for the collection of the costs of such repair against said person
making the opening. (Ord. 815, 11-7-2022)
7-2-5: LOCATION OF EXCAVATION AREA REQUIRED:
Prior to the commencement of any boring, cutting or excavation of any street,
highway or alley, or in any right of way or easement adjacent to any street,
highway or alley, the party conducting said excavation shall mark off, with
white spray paint or other appropriate indicators, the area which is planned
for excavation. Said requirement is commonly referred to as “white striping”
the area planned for excavation. (Ord. 815, 11-7-2022)
7-2-5A: FEE REQUIRED FOR STREET EXCAVATION:
Prior to the commencement of any cutting or excavation of any paved street or
highway, a fee of $500.00 shall be paid to the City of Poteau. (Ord. 815, 11-7-
2022)
7-2-6: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate this chapter or any part thereof shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine as provided in Section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 815, 11-7-2022)
CHAPTER 3
PARKS AND RECREATION
SECTION:
7-3-1: Determination And Enforcement Of Rules
7-3-2: Setting Of Fees
7-3-3: Concessions; Permit And Fee
7-3-4: Closing Hours, Compliance With
7-3-5: Rules And Regulations
7-3-6: Penalty
7-3-1: DETERMINATION AND ENFORCEMENT OF RULES:
The city council shall promulgate, invoke, create, amend and enforce such
rules, regulations, and other requirements as it deems necessary or expedient
in connection with the use of all recreational and park facilities owned or
operated by the city. (1990 Code § 11-101)
7-3-2: SETTING OF FEES:
The city shall provide by rules, from time to time, the fees charged for any
such park or recreational privileges on any property or facility for
recreational purposes owned or operated by the city. (1990 Code § 11-102)
7-3-3: CONCESSIONS; PERMIT AND FEE:
No person shall sell any food or merchandise, or conduct any concession on city
park grounds without permission from the city. The fee for a permit shall be
fixed by the city council, and permit concessions at the place designated for
such purpose by the city council. (1990 Code § 11-103)
7-3-4: CLOSING HOURS, COMPLIANCE WITH:
No person shall be allowed in any city park after its closing hours, except by
special permission of the city. (1990 Code § 11-109)
7-3-5: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Motor Vehicles:
      1.   No motor vehicle shall be driven or otherwise operated at a rate of
speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour in any city park.
      2.   The parking of motor vehicles shall be at such places designated
therefor and in accordance with regulations posted on park grounds. (1990 Code
§ 11-104)
   B.   Littering: It is unlawful for any person to litter the grounds or other
areas within the city parks and playgrounds. Persons using picnic grounds in
any city park shall clean up all papers, cans and other waste before leaving
such grounds. (1990 Code § 11-105)
   C.   Fires: It is unlawful for any person to build or set any fire inside
any city park or picnic grounds, except in ovens which have been provided for
such purposes. (1990 Code § 11-106)
   D.   Intoxicating Beverages: It is unlawful for any person to drink any
alcoholic beverage or to be intoxicated upon any city park ground. (1990 Code §
11-107)
   E.   Protection Of Wildlife: It is unlawful for any person to kill any bird
or wild animal on city park property. (1990 Code § 11-108)
   F.   Tobacco:
      1.   The use of tobacco is a public nuisance, is dangerous to adults and
children, and sets an unhealthy example for the city of Poteau's youth and
children. Therefore, the use of tobacco in any form is hereby prohibited in all
city owned parks. The use of tobacco in any form shall also be prohibited in
and around all public restrooms located in city owned parks, and in and around
all parking lots adjacent to city owned parks.
      2.   For purposes of this section, a "city owned park" shall be defined
as any parcel of open land which is owned by the city of Poteau and used for
recreational activities, including all walking and bicycle trails, ball fields,
skateparks, and other fields or facilities used for sporting events.
      3.   Any person who knowingly violates this subsection F is guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished in accordance with
the penalty provisions of section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 724, 5-7-2012)
7-3-6: PENALTY:
It is unlawful for any person to use any of the park or recreational facilities
without having complied with the rules and regulations promulgated by the city
council in connection therewith. Anyone violating any of the rules and
regulations, or failing to comply with such, shall be guilty of an offense and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1990 Code § 11-110)
CHAPTER 4
CEMETERY
SECTION:
7-4-1: Sale Of Lots; Duties Of City Clerk
7-4-2: Record Of Deeds
7-4-3: Damage To Property
7-4-4: Excavations
7-4-1: SALE OF LOTS; DUTIES OF CITY CLERK:
The city shall keep a plat of all cemetery lots, which shall at all times show
the lots that have been sold and the date of sale, to whom sold and the lots
remaining unsold in the city cemetery. The clerk shall receive money for the
price of lots sold, and a record of the names of all persons entitled to
certificates or deeds to such lots, which record must in all cases show the
receipts for the full amount due the city as shown by such record. It is
unlawful for the mayor and city clerk to execute any certificate or deed to any
person for any cemetery lots until above requirements have been complied with
by the clerk. (1990 Code § 11-201)
7-4-2: RECORD OF DEEDS:
The city clerk shall keep a record of each deed or certificate to cemetery lots
issued by the city, which record shall show the names of the purchaser, the
date of the instrument, the description of the property, and the consideration
received therefor. (1990 Code § 11-202)
7-4-3: DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
It is unlawful for any person to injure, deface or in any manner trespass upon
the city cemetery or to in any way injure any monument, grave, stone, fence,
tree, shrubbery, flowers, or any other improvements placed thereon by any
person or turn stock loose in any of the roadways in or about the cemetery.
(1990 Code § 11-203)
7-4-4: EXCAVATIONS:
All graves shall be excavated to a depth not less than four feet six inches
(4'6"), or such depth prescribed by the city, below the natural surface of the
ground, and shall be neatly moulded and smoothed with plain head and foot
boards firmly planted before they shall be deemed completed. (1990 Code § 11-
204)
CHAPTER 5
RAILROADS
SECTION:
7-5-1: Improvement Of Streets And Alleys
7-5-2: Sidewalks Constructed By Railroads
7-5-3: Climbing On Trains
7-5-4: Trains Blocking Streets
7-5-5: Speed Limit For Trains
7-5-6: Penalty
7-5-1: IMPROVEMENT OF STREETS AND ALLEYS:
   A.   Tracks Within Or Adjacent To Streets: When a railway occupies any
portion of a street with its tracks running in a general direction of such
street, either on or adjacent thereto, the railway company shall improve the
space between its tracks and two feet (2') on either side thereof in the same
manner that the remainder of the street is to be, or has been, improved, or
with such other satisfactory material as the council by motion or resolution
may approve.
   B.   Tracks Within Or Adjacent To Alleys: In case any railway company shall
occupy an alley with its track or tracks, such company shall improve, gutter,
drain, and grade such alley, and shall surface or pave it with the same
material which is to be, or has been, used on the alley, or with such other
satisfactory material as the council by motion or resolution may approve.
   C.   Crossing Streets:
      1.   When the tracks of any railroad company cross any street that is
being or has been paved, the company shall pave as much of the street as is
occupied by its track or tracks and two feet (2') on each side, using the same
material as is to be, or has been, used on the street, or such other
satisfactory material as the council by motion or resolution may approve.
      2.   When more than one track crosses a street within a distance of one
hundred feet (100'), measuring from inside rail to inside rail, the railroad
company shall grade, gutter, drain, and curb the street area between its
tracks, and surface or pave it with the same material which the city is to use
or has used, on the street.
   D.   Maintenance: Railroad companies shall keep all such improvements made
by them in a good state of repair at all times. (1990 Code § 16-101)
7-5-2: SIDEWALKS CONSTRUCTED BY RAILROADS:
Railway companies shall construct sidewalks crossing their rights of way, using
the same material as is used in adjacent sidewalks insofar as this is
practicable under the circumstances. They shall construct sidewalks on both
sides of the streets when both sides are used by pedestrians. The company shall
keep such sidewalks in a good state of repair at all times. (1990 Code § 16-
102)
7-5-3: CLIMBING ON TRAINS:
It is unlawful for any person to climb upon, hold to, or in any manner attach
himself to, any railway train, locomotive, or railway car while such is in
motion within the city, unless such person is acting in line of duty; or to
board any train or railroad car, including a passenger, freight, or other car,
except with a proper ticket or the permission of the person in charge of the
train or car or in line of duty. (1990 Code § 16-103)
7-5-4: TRAINS BLOCKING STREETS:
It is unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train
to direct the operation of, or to operate the same, in such a manner as to
prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time
longer than five (5) minutes. This provision shall not apply to railroad trains
or cars in motion, other than those engaged in switching. (1990 Code § 16-105)
7-5-5: SPEED LIMIT FOR TRAINS:
   A.   Speed Limit Specified: The maximum speed of railroad engines, motorcars
or trains of cars within the corporate limits of the city is forty five (45)
miles per hour.
   B.   Duty Of Engineer: No engineer or other person in charge of a railway
engine, motorcar or train of cars shall operate and run the same, or permit the
same to be operated and run, along any track within the corporate limits of the
city at a greater rate of speed than is prescribed and set forth in this
section. (1990 Code § 16-104)
7-5-6: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate this chapter, or any part thereof, shall be guilty
of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (1990 Code § 16-106)
TITLE 8
UTILITIES
CHAPTER 1
UTILITY SYSTEMS GENERALLY
SECTION:
8-1-1: Lease Of Systems; Public Works Authority
8-1-2: Scope Of Provisions
8-1-3: Service In Compliance With Technical Provisions
8-1-4: Authority To Establish Rules And Regulations
8-1-5: Inspection Prior To Making Water Or Sewer Taps
8-1-6: Right Of Entry
8-1-7: Termination Of Service Authorized
8-1-8: Nonliability Of City For Damage
8-1-9: Utility Service Application Required
8-1-10: Assumption Of Use
8-1-11: Use Contrary To Permit Prohibited
8-1-12: Temporary Interruption Of Service Authorized
8-1-13: Right To Restrict Use
8-1-14: Sale Of Service By Customer
8-1-15: Service Connection Regulations
8-1-16: Unlawful Use
8-1-17: Maintenance Of System By Consumer
8-1-18: Allowing Access To City And Authority Agents
8-1-1: LEASE OF SYSTEMS; PUBLIC WORKS AUTHORITY:
The city has leased its water, sewer and sanitation systems to the Poteau
public works authority, a public trust. The trust has power to set rates and
otherwise to regulate the water, sewer, and sanitation systems. The motions and
resolutions adopted by the trust replaced any ordinances which the city had
relating to these matters. For the motions and resolutions passed by the public
trust, reference should be made to the minutes of the Poteau public works
authority. A copy of the trust indenture relating to the leasing of these
systems is on file in the office of the city clerk. (1990 Code § 17-101)
8-1-2: SCOPE OF PROVISIONS:
All pertinent provisions of this chapter are hereby made a part of the terms
and conditions whereby the city shall furnish any utility service to any
person, or whereby the city shall make any utility connections, or perform any
work of any kind in connection with the furnishing of any utility service
pursuant to the rules and regulations of the city council. (1990 Code § 17-102)
8-1-3: SERVICE IN COMPLIANCE WITH TECHNICAL PROVISIONS:
Any utility service furnished under the provisions of this chapter shall be in
accordance with and in compliance with all applicable technical provisions of
this code, state law and city ordinances, rules and regulations. (1990 Code §
17-103)
8-1-4: AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The city council and the city's public works authority shall have the authority
to establish by rule or regulation such standards and specifications as may be
deemed necessary for the installation, construction and maintenance of any
utility service system owned and operated by the city within or without the
city and under the management of the city. Such rules, regulations, standards
and specifications shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. Violation of
such rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be deemed a
misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1990 Code § 17-104)
8-1-5: INSPECTION PRIOR TO MAKING WATER OR SEWER TAPS:
In order to protect the utility service supply, the city will not make any
water or sewer taps until the premises involved has been inspected and approved
by the plumbing inspector, or other agent of the city. (1990 Code § 17-105)
8-1-6: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
Any authorized inspector of the city shall have free access at any time to all
premises supplied with any utility service by the city for the purpose of
examination in order to protect the utility services from abusive use. (1990
Code § 17-106)
8-1-7: TERMINATION OF SERVICE AUTHORIZED:
The city shall have the right to disconnect or refuse to connect or reconnect
any utility service for any of the following reasons:
   A.   Failure to meet the applicable provisions of law;
   B.   Violation of the rules and regulations pertaining to utility service;
   C.   Nonpayment of bills;
   D.   Wilful or negligent waste of service due to improper or imperfect
pipes, fixtures, appliances or otherwise;
   E.   Molesting any meter, seal or other equipment controlling or regulating
the supply of utility service;
   F.   Theft or diversion or use of service without payment therefor; or
   G.   Vacancy of premises. (1990 Code § 17-107)
8-1-8: NONLIABILITY OF CITY FOR DAMAGE:
   A.   Nonliability Of City: The city shall not be liable for any damage to
any customer of any utility service furnished by the city due to backflow of
the sewerage system, failure of supply, interruption of service or any other
cause outside the direct control of the city.
   B.   Damage Beyond Meter: In case of damage beyond the meter, the city shall
not be liable for damage unless the city is duly notified and a reasonable
amount of time is allowed to correct such damage. (1990 Code § 17-108)
8-1-9: UTILITY SERVICE APPLICATION REQUIRED:
   A.   Application And Deposit 1 :
      1.   Any person desiring any utility service furnished by the city shall
make application for the same to the city clerk.
      2.   Such application shall contain the applicant's name, address and the
uses for which such utility service is desired.
      3.   Before any utility service shall be provided to an applicant
therefor, such application shall be signed by the applicant and filed with the
utility department, along with the required deposit.
   B.   Repair Of Leaks: In consideration of service to be given, the consumer
agrees that the city shall not be responsible for damages or injury caused by
escaping gas or water on consumer's side of the meter, nor for injury or damage
caused by gas or water escaping from the city's lines until after the city
shall be notified of the leaking gas or water by the consumer and be given a
reasonable time to repair the leak. (1990 Code § 17-109)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  8-2-2 of this title.
8-1-10: ASSUMPTION OF USE:
All premises connected to any utility service of the city shall be assumed to
be using such utility service and the owner or occupant shall be charged
therefor so long as such premises shall remain connected with the utility
service. (1990 Code § 17-110)
8-1-11: USE CONTRARY TO PERMIT PROHIBITED:
Any person having a permit from the city for the use of any utility service
offered by the city who shall use such utility service for any purpose other
than mentioned in such permit or who shall make any unauthorized changes in
such service shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1990 Code § 17-111)
8-1-12: TEMPORARY INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE AUTHORIZED:
The city reserves the right to cut off any utility service without notice in
case of emergencies. When an interruption in service is necessary for the
maintenance and improvement of the utility system, affected customers will be
notified as circumstances permit. (1990 Code § 17-112)
8-1-13: RIGHT TO RESTRICT USE:
The city hereby reserves the right to at any time restrict or prevent the use
of any utility service furnished by the city during periods of emergency or
circumstances demanding such restriction or prevention of use. (1990 Code § 17-
113)
8-1-14: SALE OF SERVICE BY CUSTOMER:
It is unlawful for any person to resell to others any utility service obtained
from the city except only by special arrangement with the city council. (1990
Code § 17-114)
8-1-15: SERVICE CONNECTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   City Supervision: Connections for any utility service furnished by the
city shall be made only under the supervision of the city council. (1990 Code §
17-115)
   B.   Separate Connections: Every building, structure or consumer in the city
shall have a separate city owned utility service connection, unless
specifically authorized by the city council. (1990 Code § 17-116)
   C.   Unlawful Connections: Any person who shall make any connection in any
manner to any utility system, whether owned by the city or not, without the
prior knowledge and consent of the owner of such utility shall be deemed guilty
of a misdemeanor. (1990 Code § 17-117)
8-1-16: UNLAWFUL USE:
No person, other than employees of the city, shall be authorized to connect,
turn on, turn off, disconnect or reconnect any utility service offered by the
city, or remove, replace or repair any equipment connected to any such utility
service. (1990 Code § 17-118)
8-1-17: MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM BY CONSUMER:
The consumer of any utility service furnished by the city shall maintain and
keep in good repair all connections, appliances and other apparatus installed
and used in connection with such utility service. (1990 Code § 17-119)
8-1-18: ALLOWING ACCESS TO CITY AND AUTHORITY AGENTS:
   A.   Obstructing Access Prohibited: It is unlawful and an offense for any
person to obstruct or deny access to, or prevent the reading of, water meters
in the city by the city, its agents, employees, or officers by parking any
vehicle or placing any obstruction over or on top of the water meter covers or
to permit any vehicle to be parked or located above or on top of the water
meters. Each day's continuation of any such violation shall be deemed a
separate offense.
   B.   Threats Against City Officers And Employees: It is unlawful to make
threats of any type to officers, agents, or employees of the city in the
performance of their duties or to prevent the officers, agents, or employees
from performing their official duties in reading the water meters or by
limiting the access to water meters in any other manner not limited to those
mentioned above. (1990 Code § 17-120)
CHAPTER 2
UTILITY RATES AND CHARGES

8-2-1: UTILITY METERS:
   A.   Meters Required: Meters for the measurement of utility services
furnished by the City shall be furnished and installed by, and shall remain the
property of, the City. (1990 Code § 17-201)
   B.   Access To Meters: Free access to utility meters shall be granted the
City at all reasonable times. (1990 Code § 17-202)
8-2-2: DEPOSIT FOR UTILITY SERVICE 1 :
   A.   Deposit Required: Every applicant for utility service shall make a
deposit with the City Clerk in an amount to be determined by resolution passed
by the City Council, and such applicant shall not be granted utility service
until he has paid to the City Clerk such deposit. The deposit shall serve as a
guarantee for the payment of charges for utility service and other amounts owed
to the City in connection with such service. (1990 Code § 17-203)
   B.   Refund Of Deposit: Refunds of deposits made for utility service shall
be made upon the termination of such utility service only after payment of all
indebtedness to the City for such utility service. Application of the deposit
may be made in partial or total settlement of accounts when the supply is cut
off for nonpayment of the bill, or for any infraction or violation of any
ordinance, rule or regulation of the City relative to utility services offered
by the City. (1990 Code § 17-204)

8-2-3: PAYMENT OF BILLS; DELINQUENCY; SERVICE DISCONTINUED:
   A.   Time Of Payment; Delinquency: All bills for utility services furnished
by the City shall be due and payable when rendered and shall be considered
delinquent ten (10) days thereafter. A delinquent bill shall become subject to
immediate discontinuance of service when the next bill is rendered showing a
previous balance due. (1990 Code § 17-206)
   B.   Penalty For Failure To Pay: In the event any consumer of utility
services furnished by the City shall fail to pay his bill therefor when the
same is due, a penalty as determined by the City Council shall be imposed.
(1990 Code § 17-207)
   C.   Reconnection After Disconnection: In the event that utility service is
disconnected for nonpayment of the bill, the consumer thereof shall have the
right to have the same reconnected only upon the payment of the amount due, and
in addition thereto, a reconnection fee as established by the city council from
time to time. (1990 Code § 17-208)
8-2-4: VOLUNTARY DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
Consumers wishing to discontinue the use of any utility service shall give
written notice thereof at the city hall. Failure to do so shall render them
liable for the payment of all bills until such notice has been given. (1990
Code § 17-209)
8-2-5: DETERMINATION OF CHARGES GENERALLY:
The rates and charges for the consumption of utility services furnished by the
city, as well as the charges and fees for connection thereto, shall be as
determined by the city council or the public works authority from time to time,
and such service and connection charges and fees shall be and remain on file in
the office of the city clerk. (1990 Code § 17-205)
8-2-6: CHARGES FOR DWELLING UNITS WITHOUT SEPARATE METERS:
From and after February 3, 2020, the new rates for water users or customers in
the city who reside in dwelling units without separate meters, and specifically
in the case of individual mobile homes in any mobile home park and individual
housekeeping units within any apartment, which mobile home or unit does not
have a separate meter, there shall be additional charges of:
 
Sewer                                $5.81 per month
Sanitation                           5.12 per month
Oklahoma solid waste management act1 5.30 per month
Water                                10.56 per month
 
for a total of twenty-five dollars and twenty cents ($25.20) per month for each
such mobile home or housekeeping unit, a "housekeeping unit" being a unit with
kitchen facilities or privileges for family functions. (Ord. 523, 7-3-1995;
amd. Ord. 781, 2-3-2020; Ord. 802, 8-2-2021)
8-2-7: WATER METERED FOR RESALE, COLLECTION OF CHARGES:
   A.   Responsibility For Collection Of Charges: Should water be sold by the
city and metered to a person for sale to water consumers who are users of the
city sewer and sanitation systems, the first purchaser shall be responsible to
the city for billing and collecting from all his water customers who are users
of the city sewer and sanitation systems, and shall account to the city for all
charges including: water, sewer, sanitation, and Oklahoma solid waste
management act (OSWMA) charges at the time such first user of water pays his
water bill.
   B.   Maintenance Of Records: Such person reselling such water shall maintain
adequate records and shall furnish and certify, upon request, the number and
names of all of his water customers who are users of the city water, sewer, and
sanitation services. (Ord. 523, 7-3-1995)
8-2-8: RATES FOR THE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE FOR COMMERCIAL
CUSTOMERS IN THE CITY:
Effective August 1, 2020, the rates applicable for the collection of garbage
for commercial customers shall be as follows:
 
Non dumpster commercial               $13.05
Dumpster (1-2 times per week pick-up) 26.10
Dumpster (3-4 times per week pick-up) 39.15
