distance parallel to and from the front lot line.
(1990 Code § 12-232)
11-6A-4: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
The maximum coverage of any lot in the R-1 district shall not exceed fifty
percent (50%) of the lot area for interior lots nor sixty percent (60%) of the
lot area for corner lots. (1990 Code § 12-233)
11-6A-5: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
The following minimum requirements for yards shall apply to any use that is
constructed or commenced on a parcel of land in the R-1 district:
 
Permitted Use          Front Yard Side Yards Rear Yard
                                  Both One
Single-family dwelling 25'        15'  5'    20% lot depth
 
(1990 Code § 12-234)
11-6A-6: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: No dwelling in the R-1 district shall be constructed with
a height in excess of forty feet (40') from the mean lot elevation nor will it
exceed three (3) stories.
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): Bulk limitations in the R-
1 district are governed by maximum coverage, yard requirements and height
limitations as provided in this article. (1990 Code §§ 12-235, 12-236; amd.
Ord. 824, 12-4-2023)
11-6A-7: OFF STREET PARKING:
Except as provided for elsewhere in this title, all permitted uses in the R-
1 residence district shall comply with the following minimum requirements for
off street parking:
 
Single-family dwellings                 1 space for each dwelling unit
Schools, elementary schools, junior and 1 space for each employee, plus 1 for
senior high schools, including public,  each classroom, plus 1 for each 50
private and parochial schools           square feet of assembly area with
                                        stationary or moveable seats
                                        1 space for each 5 seats provided for
                                        patron use, or 1 space for each 400
                                        square feet of gross floor area used or
                                        intended to be used for service to the
Other uses permitted in section         public as customers, patrons, or
11-6A-2 of this article                 clients, whichever requires the
                                        greatest number of parking spaces; the
                                        open space required by front yard
                                        requirement shall not be used for
                                        parking
Utilities services installations        1 space for each 400 square feet of
                                        floor space
 
(1990 Code § 12-237)
11-6A-8: SEWER SERVICE:
No dwelling unit in an R-1 district shall be constructed that is not provided
with an effective connection to a public sewerage system unless or until the
health officer certifies that a septic tank or any substitute disposal system
can be satisfactorily installed on the lot. As a basis for making his decision,
the health officer may require such precaution tests as he deems to be
necessary. Such tests are to be made at the expense of the homeowner. (1990
Code § 12-238)
11-6A-9: SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS:
No signs, billboards, posters, bulletin boards or other similar matter shall be
permitted in the R-1 residence district, except as follows:
   A.   Temporary signs not to exceed the duration of six (6) months to
advertise the premises for sale, rent or lease, except original sale;
   B.   One bulletin board not exceeding fifty (50) square feet may be erected
by each church;
   C.   Official public notices may be erected on affected property; or
   D.   One unilluminated nameplate not exceeding two (2) square feet in area,
and not containing lettering other than the name of the owner or occupant or
name or address of the premises. (1990 Code § 12-239)
ARTICLE B. R-2 ONE-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-6B-1: General Description
11-6B-2: Permitted Uses
11-6B-3: Minimum Lot Size
11-6B-4: Maximum Coverage
11-6B-5: Yard Requirements

11-6B-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION:
The R-2 one-family residence district is designed specifically to provide an
area for single-family housing at a higher density than permitted in the R-
1 district. The development and continued use of this land for single-family
dwellings is encouraged, and the encroachment of commercial and industrial use
or any other use which would substantially interfere with the development of or
continuation of this district as single-family dwellings is prohibited. This
article also discourages any use which would generate traffic or create
congestion on neighborhood streets other than normal traffic which serves the
residences on the street. It also encourages only those uses which, because of
character or size, would not create additional requirements and costs for
public services which are in excess of such requirements and costs if the
district were developed solely for single-family dwellings. (1990 Code § 12-
240)
11-6B-2: PERMITTED USES:
Permitted uses in the R-2 residence district are the same as those in section
11-6A-2 of this title, for the R-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-241)
11-6B-3: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:
No dwelling or use shall be constructed or commended in the R-2 district which
does not conform with the following minimum requirements for lot size:
 
Dwelling Unit Type Minimum Front Feet Minimum Lot Area
Single-family      50 ft.*            6,000 sq. ft.
 
*   The frontage of any wedge shaped lot which meets the requirements of
minimum lot size may be a minimum of forty feet (40'); however the front
building line on the lot shall be a minimum of fifty (50) linear feet, measured
at an equal distance parallel to and from the front lot line.
Beginning April 4, 2022, all housing developments in the R-2 District shall
have a minimum frontage of sixty (60) linear feet.
(1990 Code § 12-242; amd. Ord. 810, 4-4-2022)
11-6B-4: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
The maximum coverage of any lot in the R-2 district shall not exceed fifty
percent (50%) of the lot area for interior lots or sixty percent (60%) of the
lot area for corner lots. (1990 Code § 12-243)

constructed or commenced on a parcel of land in the R-2 district:
 
Permitted use          Front Yard Side Yards
                                  Both One Rear Yard
Single-family dwelling 25’      15’5’20% lot depth
 
(1990 Code § 12-244; amd. Ord. 810, 4-4-2022)
11-6B-6: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: No dwelling in the R-2 district shall be constructed with
a height in excess of forty feet (40') from the mean lot elevation nor will it
exceed three (3) stories.
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): Bulk limitations in the R-
2 district are governed by maximum coverage, yard requirements and height
limitations as provided in this article. (1990 Code §§ 12-245, 12-246; amd.
Ord. 824, 12-4-2023)
11-6B-7: OFF STREET PARKING:
In the R-2 residence district, the off street parking requirements are the same
as those in section
11-6A-7 of this title, for the R-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-247)
11-6B-8: SEWER SERVICE:
No dwelling unit in an R-2 district shall be constructed that is not provided
with an effective connection to a public sewerage system unless and until the
health officer certifies that a septic tank or any substitute disposal system
can be satisfactorily installed on the lot. As a basis for making his decision,
the health officer may require such precaution tests as he deems to be
necessary. Such tests are to be made at the expense of the homeowner. (1990
Code § 12-248)
11-6B-9: SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS:
The control of signs and billboards in the R-2 residence district are the same
as that in section
11-6A-9 of this title, for the R-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-249)
ARTICLE C. R-3 TWO-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICT
SECTION:

11-6C-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION:
The R-3 residence district is designed to permit a higher density of
residential use upon land. This does not provide for multi- family use in this
district. It is the intent of this article to encourage the development of and
the continued use of the land for two-family dwellings and to prohibit
commercial and industrial uses or any other use which would substantially
interfere with the development or continuation of two-family dwellings in this
district. This article also discourages any use which would generate traffic or
create congestion on neighborhood streets other than the normal traffic which
serves the residents in this district. This article also encourages only those
uses which, because of character or size, would not create additional
requirements and costs for public services which are in excess of such
requirements and costs if the district were developed solely for two-family
dwellings. (1990 Code § 12-250)
11-6C-2: PERMITTED USES:
In the R-3 residence district, structures may be used, altered, enlarged or
erected for the uses listed in section
11-6A-2 of this chapter, for the R-1 district, with the addition of the
following use:
Two-family dwellings. (1990 Code § 12-251)
11-6C-3: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:

Two-family         80 feet1      8,000 square feet
 
Note:

lot size, the frontage may be a minimum of 40 feet; however, the front building
line on the lot shall be a minimum of 80 linear feet, measured at an equal
distance parallel to and from the front lot line.
(1990 Code § 12-252; amd. per correspondence dated 9-12-2014)
11-6C-4: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:

percent (60%) of the lot area for corner lots. (1990 Code § 12-253)

limitations as provided in this article. (1990 Code §§ 12-255, 12-256; amd.

ARTICLE D. R-4 MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-6D-1: General Description
11-6D-2: Permitted Uses
11-6D-3: Minimum Lot Size
11-6D-4: Maximum Coverage
11-6D-5: Yard Requirements
11-6D-6: Height And Bulk

11-6D-8: Sewer Service
11-6D-9: Signs And Billboards
11-6D-10: Mobile Home Trailer Parks
11-6D-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION:
The R-4 residence district is established as a district in which the principal
uses of the land are for multi-family dwellings and similar high density
residential development. It is the intent of this article to encourage the
development and the continued use of the land for multi-family dwellings and to
prohibit commercial and industrial uses or any other use which would
substantially interfere with the development or continuation of multi-family
dwellings in this district. It is further intended that this article shall
discourage any use which would generate traffic or create congestion on the
neighborhood streets other than the normal traffic which serves the multi-
family dwellings or similar residential uses in this district. This article
further discourages any use which, because of its characteristics or size,
would create additional requirements and cost for public services which are in
excess of such requirements and costs if the district were developed solely for
multi-family or other similar residential uses. (1990 Code § 12-260)
11-6D-2: PERMITTED USES:
In the R-4 residence district, structures may be used, altered, enlarged or
erected for the uses listed in section
11-6C-2 of this title, for the R-3 district, with the addition of the following
uses:
Multi-family dwelling units; or
Mobile home trailer courts when in compliance with section
11-6D-10 of this article. (1990 Code § 12-261)
11-6D-3: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:
No dwelling structure or use shall be constructed or commenced in the R-
4 district which does not conform with the following minimum requirements for
lot size:
 
Dwelling Unit Type Minimum Front Feet Minimum Lot Area Per Dwelling Unit
Single-family      70 ft.*            8,000 sq. ft.
Two-family         70 ft.*            4,000 sq. ft.
Multi-family       70 ft.*            2,400 sq. ft.
 
*If the lot is a wedge shaped lot which meets the requirements of minimum lot
size, it may have less than the minimum requirements for frontage as long as
the front building line on the lot is a minimum of seventy (70) linear feet.
(1990 Code § 12-262)
11-6D-4: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
The maximum coverage of any lot in the R-4 district shall not exceed sixty
percent (60%) of the area for interior lots nor seventy five percent (75%) of
the lot area for corner lots. (1990 Code § 12-263)
11-6D-5: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
The following minimum requirements for yards shall apply to any use that is
constructed or commenced on a parcel of land in the R-4 district:
 
Permitted Use          Front Yard Side Yards Rear Yard
                                  Both One
Single-family dwelling 30'        15'  5'    20% lot depth
Two-family             30'        15'  5'    20% lot depth
Multi-family           30'        15'  5'    20% lot depth
 
(1990 Code § 12-264)
11-6D-6: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: No dwelling structure in the R-4 district shall be
constructed with a height in excess of forty feet (40') from the mean lot
elevation nor shall it be more than three (3) stories. (1990 Code § 12-265)
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): Bulk limitations in the R-
4 district are governed by maximum coverage, yard requirements and height
limitations as provided in this article. (1990 Code § 12-266)
11-6D-7: OFF STREET PARKING:
In the R-4 residence district, the off street parking requirements are the same
as those in section
11-6C-7 of this title, for the R-3 district, with the addition of the following
provision for off street parking in the multi-family residence district:
 
Multi-family dwellings 1 1/2 spaces for each dwelling unit
 
(1990 Code § 12-267)
11-6D-8: SEWER SERVICE:
No dwelling unit in an R-4 district shall be constructed that is not provided
with an effective connection to a public sewerage system unless and until the
health officer certifies that a septic tank or any substitute disposal system
can be satisfactorily installed on the lot. As a basis for making his decision,
the health officer may require such precaution tests as he deems to be
necessary. Such tests are to be made at the expense of the homeowner. (1990
Code § 12-268)
11-6D-9: SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS:
The control of signs and billboards in the R-4 residence district are the same
as that in section
11-6A-9 of this title, for the R-1 residence district. (1990 Code § 12-269)
11-6D-10: MOBILE HOME TRAILER PARKS:
Upon compliance with the provisions as set forth herein, the planning
commission may authorize a mobile home trailer park within the R-4 residence
district:
   A.   Site Plan Required With Application: The applicant, upon making
application for a zoning clearance permit, must submit to the planning
commission a detailed site plan locating all mobile home stands, screening or
fencing, and plans and specifications for the proposed park in a form suitable
for making the determinations required herein.
   B.   Site Specifications:
      1.   The proposed site shall be a minimum of two and one-half (21/2)
acres in size and shall contain no more than fifteen (15) mobile home stands
per acre.
      2.   The proposed site shall have a minimum frontage of two hundred feet
(200') on a street designated as a major street or collector street in the
major street plan. All access or egress by automobile will be on such streets.
      3.   The proposed site shall be a minimum of two hundred feet (200') in
depth.
   C.   Permanent Occupancy And Transient Stands:
      1.   It shall be the intention of the proposed plan for the mobile home
park to accommodate primarily permanent occupants with no more than ten percent
(10%) nor less than five percent (5%) of the mobile home stands devoted to
purely transient purposes.
      2.   These purely transient stands are to be located in one area of the
park so they will in no way interfere with the permanent residents.
   D.   Off Street Parking: The proposed site shall provide one off street
parking space for each mobile home stand, plus one additional off street
parking space for each four (4) mobile homes stands.
   E.   Public Utilities Connection: The proposed site shall provide a
connection for each mobile home stand to all public utilities considered
necessary for the health, safety and general welfare of the public. (1990 Code
§ 12-270)
CHAPTER 7
COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS
ARTICLE A. C-1 CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-7A-1: General Description; Purpose
11-7A-2: Permitted Uses
11-7A-3: Minimum Lot Size
11-7A-4: Maximum Coverage
11-7A-5: Yard Requirements
11-7A-6: Height And Bulk
11-7A-7: Off Street Parking
11-7A-8: Sewer Service
11-7A-9: Signs And Billboards
11-7A-10: Canopies And Awnings
11-7A-11: Conditional Uses
11-7A-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION; PURPOSE:
   A.   Description: The C-1 central business district is established as the
district in the city which serves as the center of the surrounding regional
retail market area. The principal use of the land in this district is for
commercial and service purposes.
   B.   Purpose: The purpose of this district is to encourage the development
of, and the continued use of, the land for commercial and service purposes
which serve the regional area of the city. The existing development in this
district is of such a degree that it would not be feasible to require off
street parking and loading regulations in the same degree that off street
parking and loading regulations can be required for new commercial developments
in undeveloped land. The specific intent of this district further provides for
the orderly expansion of the uses that are allowed in this district; also, that
heavier commercial and industrial uses of the land which would substantially
interfere with the continuation of the existing uses, or the proposed orderly
development of this district, are prohibited. It is further intended to
minimize traffic and parking congestion in such a manner as to provide for the
safety and convenience of shoppers, visitors and other pedestrians in the
district by discouraging any use which, because of its character or size, would
create abnormal traffic congestion, fire or safety hazards in the district.
(1990 Code § 12-280)
11-7A-2: PERMITTED USES:
All building or uses hereafter established or enlarged shall comply with the
conditions and restrictions provided for in this article:
Appliance and furniture stores.
Automotive repair and sales.
Bakery whose products are sold at retail on the premises.
Banks and financial institutions.
Barbershops.
Beauty shops.
Bowling alleys.
Branch bank.
Bus and rail terminal facilities.
Cafes and taverns.
Clothing or wearing apparel shops.
Clubs, private and public.
Drugstores.
Gasoline service stations.
Grocery stores or supermarkets.
Hotels.
Laundry and dry cleaning pick up stations.
Medical offices and buildings.
Offices.
Post offices.
Public and private parking lots.
Repair and service of automobiles carried on in the same building.
Restaurants, including drive-ins.
Retail tire sales and supply.
Retail use where no fabrication or manufacture takes place on the premises.
Self-service laundry.
Shoe repair shops.
Store or shop for the conducting of a convenience type or service type retail
business where there is no manufacture or prefabrication of a product or
merchandise.
Theaters. (1990 Code § 12-281)
11-7A-3: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:
There are no requirements for minimum lot size in the C-1 central business
district. (1990 Code § 12-282)
11-7A-4: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
There are no requirements of maximum coverage in the C-1 central business
district. (1990 Code § 12-283)
11-7A-5: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
There are no yard requirements in the C-1 central business district. (1990 Code
§ 12-284)
11-7A-6: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: No structure in the C-1 central business district shall
be constructed with a height in excess of fifty feet (50') from the mean lot
elevation nor will it exceed four (4) stories.
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): The floor area ratio of any
principal structure or its accessory structures in the C-1 central business
district is not to exceed five (5) times that of the net lot area for buildings
of more than one story in height. (1990 Code §§ 12-285, 12-286; amd. Ord. 824,
12-4-2023)
11-7A-7: OFF STREET PARKING:
There are no requirements for off street parking in the C-1 district except as
provided in subsection 11-7A-11C of this article. (1990 Code § 12-287)
11-7A-8: SEWER SERVICE:
No structure in the C-1 district may be erected or allowed to continue after
the effective date of this title that does not have an effective connection to
the public sewer system, unless or until the health officer certifies that it
is not a requirement for the specific health needs of that structure and does
not jeopardize the health, welfare and safety of others. (1990 Code § 12-288)
11-7A-9: SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS:
All signs in the C-1 district shall be erected upon private property and shall
not encroach upon any public street or walk, except as provided by the
applicable codes of the city, and then they shall not overhang at a height of
less than nine feet (9') and shall not have a maximum projection greater than
seventy two inches (72"):
   A.   Projecting Signs; Flat Signs: Any projecting sign in the C-1 district
shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet in size, nor will it exceed the height
of the building if the building exceeds thirty five feet (35'), nor will any
flat sign exceed three hundred (300) square feet in size.
   B.   Incandescent Lighting: No source of incandescent lighting used for
illuminating signs shall be directly visible from any street or highway or from
any residence, hotel or from any room used for sleeping purposes.
   C.   Lighting; Confusion With Traffic Signals: The use of red, green or
amber illumination in connection with any sign shall not be permitted within
one hundred feet (100') of an intersection. Any use of red, green or amber
illumination in connection with any sign must be so located that it in no way
creates a confusion with any traffic signal or may be interpreted by any
motorist as a traffic signaling device. (1990 Code § 12-289)
11-7A-10: CANOPIES AND AWNINGS:
Canopies and awnings may project over the walkway area, provided they are a
minimum of eight feet (8') above the city established sidewalk elevation and
are a minimum of two feet (2') from the curb or edge of the normal traveled way
or curb parking area. (1990 Code § 12-290)
11-7A-11: CONDITIONAL USES:
   A.   Commission Approval: With the approval of the planning commission, the
following uses will be permitted in the C-1 district, subject to the
restrictions as specified herein.
   B.   Uses Listed: The uses listed herein are conditional uses for the C-
1 district and do not apply to any other district:
      1.   Broadcasting studios;
      2.   Lumber yards (retail sales only); and
      3.   Pool halls or billiard parlors.
   C.   Off Street Parking: These uses shall provide off street parking with
ingress and egress designed so as to minimize traffic congestion, at the rate
of one space for each four hundred (400) square feet of floor space used. In
addition, there shall be provided two (2) spaces for each three (3) employees
or fraction thereof of off street parking for company owned vehicles. This off
street parking restriction may be altered by the planning commission in
individual instances where the applicant can prove that his operation will in
no way interfere with the parking needs of other authorized uses in the
district, nor will his operation create a congestion of traffic on the street.
The applicant must also show that adequate controls or measures will be taken
to prevent offensive noise, light, vibration, odor or any other objectional
influence beyond his property line. (1990 Code § 12-291)
ARTICLE B. C-2 PLANNED SHOPPING CENTER DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-7B-1: General Description; Purpose
11-7B-2: Permitted Uses
11-7B-3: Minimum Lot Size
11-7B-4: Maximum Coverage
11-7B-5: Yard Requirements
11-7B-6: Height And Bulk
11-7B-7: Off Street Parking And Loading
11-7B-8: Sewer Service
11-7B-9: Signs And Billboards
11-7B-10: District Zoning; Application And Information Required
11-7B-11: Site Development Plan
11-7B-12: Nonconforming Use Prohibited
11-7B-13: Relationship To Street Plan
11-7B-14: Developer's Costs For Improvements
11-7B-15: Preliminary Development Plan
11-7B-16: Commencement And Completion Of Construction
11-7B-17: Dedication Restrictions
11-7B-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION; PURPOSE:
   A.   Description: The C-2 planned shopping center district is established to
provide goods and services for an expanding population of the city and its
environs in locations that will fulfill the needs of the surrounding
neighborhoods.
   B.   Purpose: The purpose of the planned shopping center district is to
permit the establishment of retail shopping facilities for a neighborhood or
group of neighborhoods in such locations that will maximize the services to be
performed to the expanding population and yet minimize traffic congestion on
thoroughfares and public streets in its market area. It is the specific intent
of this article to provide standards of site development with the intention of
minimizing adverse effects of the shopping center upon nearby properties. (1990
Code § 12-300)
11-7B-2: PERMITTED USES:
All buildings or uses hereafter established or enlarged shall comply with the
conditions and restrictions provided for in this article:
Appliance and furniture stores.
Bakery whose products are sold at retail on the premises.
Barbershops.
Beauty shops.
Branch banks.
Clothing or wearing apparel shops.
Drugstores.
Gasoline service stations.
Grocery stores or supermarkets.
Laundry and dry cleaning pick up stations.
Offices.
Public and private parking lots.
Restaurants, including drive-ins.
Self-service laundries.
Shoe repair shops.
Store or shop for the conducting of a convenience or service type retail
business where there is no manufacture or prefabrication of a product or
merchandise. (1990 Code § 12-301)
11-7B-3: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:
In the C-2 district, there must be provided a minimum lot size of two (2)
acres; however, in all instances except the minimum lot size, the size of the
lot is dependent upon bulk limitations to be imposed upon the land. (1990 Code
§ 12-302)
11-7B-4: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
The maximum coverage of any building on any parcel of land in the C-2 district
is not to exceed twenty percent (20%) of the net lot area. (1990 Code § 12-303)
11-7B-5: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
Any building or structure in the C-2 district with a location above the ground
must, at a minimum, be located fifty feet (50') from any public structure or
right of way line adjoining the district. Also, any building line in this
district must be a minimum of fifteen feet (15') from the property line of any
commercial (C-1, C-3) district, or any industrial (I-1 or I-2) district. Any
building in the C-2 district will, at a minimum, be seventy five feet (75')
from any residential district. Except for the required screening, the setback
area may be used for traffic circulation and parking or loading. The C-
2 district shall be permanently screened from adjoining and contiguous
districts by a solid wall, fence, or other similar enclosure with a minimum
height of four and one-half feet (41/2') and maximum height of seven feet (7').
The planning commission may waive the requirement for a screening enclosure or
screening area if equivalent screening is provided by topography or other
natural conditions. (1990 Code § 12-304)
11-7B-6: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: In the C-2 district, no building, sign or structure, or
portion thereof, shall exceed a height of fifty feet (50') from the mean lot
elevation nor will it exceed four (4) stories.
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): In no instance shall the total
floor space of the structures in this district exceed the relationship of one
to four (1:4); i.e., there must be provided four (4) square feet of open space
to each one square foot of floor space in the structures. (1990 Code §§ 12-305,
12-306)
11-7B-7: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
In the C-2 district, three (3) square feet of space, dedicated to parking and
automobile maneuvering, must be provided for each one square foot of floor
space. There must also be provided one off street loading space for each twenty
five thousand (25,000) square feet of floor space. (1990 Code § 12-307)
11-7B-8: SEWER SERVICE:
No structure or use in the C-2 district shall be erected or commenced which
does not have a connection to the public sewage system, considered adequate and
effective by the health officer. As a basis for making his decision, the health
officer may require such precaution tests as he deems to be necessary. Such
tests are to be made at the expense of the landowner. (1990 Code § 12-308)
11-7B-9: SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS:
In the C-2 district, the control of signs and billboards are the same as those
in section
11-7A-9 of this title, for the C-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-309)
11-7B-10: DISTRICT ZONING; APPLICATION AND INFORMATION REQUIRED:
   A.   Market Analysis: The applicant shall submit a market analysis
acceptable to the city council and planning commission, and conducted and
signed by either a recognized independent market analyst or by the applicant
himself; provided, that the market analysis shall contain the following
elements:
      1.   The trade area of the proposed shopping center;
      2.   Trade area population, present and future;
      3.   Effective buying power in the trade area;
      4.   Net potential customer buying power for stores in the proposed
shopping center; and
      5.   Residue of buying power to be expended in existing shopping centers
or commercial areas serving the trade area.
   B.   Evaluation: The market analysis shall serve as a guide to the city
council and planning commission for the evaluation of the application in terms
of:
      1.   The need or desirability to change the comprehensive zoning plan in
the public interest.
      2.   The amount of land included in the rezoning application which can be
realistically supported in commercial use.
      3.   A finding that the proposed development will promote the general
welfare of the city.
   C.   Duty Of Developer Prior To Rezone: Prior to the submission of the
proposed ordinance rezoning an area to a C-2 planned shopping center district,
the developer shall submit all evidence deemed necessary by the council, or the
planning commission of his ability to undertake the proposed project. (1990
Code § 12-310)
11-7B-11: SITE DEVELOPMENT PLAN:
   A.   Submission And Approval Of Plan: No building permit shall be issued for
any structure in a C-2 district until a final site development plan for the
entire district has been submitted and approved by the planning commission as
complying with the regulations and the requirements of this article and all
other applicable city ordinances.
   B.   Agreement To Provide Facilities: No building permit shall be issued
until the developer and the city have entered into an agreement to provide for
facilities as required in sections
11-7B-14 and
11-7B-16 of this article concerning the rededication of such vacated streets or
alleys, the replatting of property in the event the proposed shopping center is
not constructed and the proposed traffic control construction, and provided
further, the agreement may contain a provision requiring the developer to post
a good and sufficient bond running to the city with two (2) or more securities
or with a security company licensed to do business in the state as security and
in an amount equal to the estimated cost of the street and utility development
in the project, conditioned that the developers shall faithfully perform all
the provisions of the contract concerning the development of the streets and
utilities in the project and shall have the city free and harmless from all
losses and damages occasioned to any person or property as a result of the
developer performing the provisions of the contract.
   C.   Failure To Proceed; Reclassification: Such agreement shall further
provide that if the developer fails to proceed with the construction within the
time provided for in this article, that such area be reclassified in a manner
consistent with the comprehensive zoning plan and shall take no further action
to construct buildings in the development other than to complete any buildings
under actual construction. Any agreements in connection with such development
shall become null and void upon reclassification of the property.
   D.   Approval Of Changes: No changes shall be made in the final site
development plan, and during the course of construction pursuant thereto,
without first obtaining the prior approval of the planning commission.
   E.   Copies Of Plan On File: Copies of the approved final site development
plan shall be kept on file with the planning commission and any changes which
may be approved shall be noted thereon.
   F.   Filing Procedures: Procedures for filing the approval of the
construction plan for buildings, structures and other improvements shall be as
now required under the city building codes. (1990 Code § 12-311)
11-7B-12: NONCONFORMING USE PROHIBITED:
A C-2 district shall not be established on a tract of land which would contain
a nonconforming use after the passage of such amendments to the zoning
regulations unless the development plan for the tract included the elimination
of the nonconforming use. (1990 Code § 12-312)
11-7B-13: RELATIONSHIP TO STREET PLAN:
The location of a C-2 district shall have an acceptable relationship to the
major street plan. For this purpose, the petitioner shall submit to the
planning commission a traffic circulation plan showing the adequacy of the
streets providing access to the shopping center to carry the traffic generated
by the shopping center, proper methods of ingress and egress to and from the
center, necessary acceleration and deceleration lanes and necessary traffic
control devices including channelization. (1990 Code § 12-313)
11-7B-14: DEVELOPER'S COSTS FOR IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Required Facilities: A petitioner or developer shall be required to pay
the cost of the construction or installation of the following facilities on the
streets providing access to the shopping center which may be necessary to
control traffic generated by the shopping center:
      1.   Street widening;
      2.   Ingress and egress driveways;
      3.   Acceleration and deceleration lanes; and
      4.   Traffic control devices and signs, including channelization.
   B.   Determining Extent Of Financial Responsibility:
      1.   The standard for determining the extent of the developer's financial
responsibility for traffic control for construction shall be the predictable
increment of traffic caused by the shopping center over the normal peak load
estimated for the use upon completion of the shopping center on the streets
providing access to it.
      2.   In the event that the developer is found to be responsible for any
such traffic control construction, such responsibilities shall be made the
subject of a contractual agreement between the developer and the city;
provided, that in such event, the developer shall be required to construct
proper ingress and egress driveways to the shopping center and street curbing
as required by city ordinances.
      3.   The length of time the developer may be held responsible for further
traffic control construction shall be specified in such contractual agreement
and such contract, or a separate contract, may contain provisions for other
street construction to be done by the developer as may be agreed upon between
the developer and the city. (1990 Code § 12-314)
11-7B-15: PRELIMINARY DEVELOPMENT PLAN:
The petitioner shall submit to the planning commission a preliminary
development plan for the shopping center showing a unified and organized
arrangement of buildings, off street parking, internal traffic circulation and
service facilities, all of which are found to be feasible and compatible with
the property on which the center is proposed and which planned development
shall minimize any adverse effect of the center and on the properties
surrounding the proposed development. The plan must contain information showing
compliance with the requirements of this section and all other applicable city
ordinances. (1990 Code § 12-315)
11-7B-16: COMMENCEMENT AND COMPLETION OF CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Building Permit Required; Time Limit: A building permit must be secured
and construction begun in accordance with the approved final site development
plan for a C-2 district within one year from the effective date of the
ordinance establishing such district. Application may be made to the planning
commission for not more than a one year extension of the time limit for
commencement of construction. In the event that construction is not started
within the specified time limit, the planning commission shall review the
zoning of the district and the progress which has taken place, and, if deemed
necessary, initiate necessary proceedings to restore the district to its prior
classification.
   B.   Construction Time; Extension: Construction begun in accordance with the
approved final site development plan for a C-2 district must be completed
within three (3) years of the date construction is commenced. Application may
be made to the planning commission for not more than a one year extension of
the time limit for completion of construction. A plan for stage development
setting forth the time for each stage and percent to be completed at each stage
may be approved by the planning commission at the time the C-2 district zoning
is recommended. In the event that construction is not completed within the time
limit specified by the planning commission or by this article, the planning
commission shall review the zoning of the district and the development which
has taken place, and, if necessary, initiate proceedings to reclassify the
district in a manner consistent with the comprehensive plan. (1990 Code § 12-
316)
11-7B-17: DEDICATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Ownership Of Land; Dedications: A C-2 district may be established only
upon land held in single ownership or under unified control and which land
contains no dedication of public streets or alleys, except streets which may be
deemed necessary by the city for the movement of vehicular traffic which has
both its origin and destination outside the C-2 district, and except any rights
of way for public utilities purposes.
   B.   Petition For Vacation: In the event that a vacation of streets, alleys,
or plats is necessary in order to meet the requirement of this section, a
proper petition for such vacation shall be filed with the city on or before the
date of filing of a request for C-2 district zoning.
   C.   Rededication: Rededication of such streets or alleys or replatting of
property to be done in the event that the proposed shopping center is not
constructed may be provided for in a contractual agreement between the
developer and the city. (1990 Code § 12-317)
ARTICLE C. C-3 LOCAL AND THROUGH HIGHWAY BUSINESS DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-7C-1: General Description
11-7C-2: Permitted Uses
11-7C-3: Minimum Lot Size
11-7C-4: Maximum Coverage
11-7C-5: Yard Requirements
11-7C-6: Height And Bulk
11-7C-7: Off Street Parking And Loading
11-7C-8: Sewer Service
11-7C-9: Signs And Billboards
11-7C-10: Additional Provisions
11-7C-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION:
The purpose of the C-3 local and through highway business district is to
provide a common location which caters mainly to through traffic which requires
conveniently grouped rest and refreshment, auto maintenance and lodging stops.
It is the intent to group these businesses not only for convenience purposes
but because highway businesses are inclined to be brightly lighted. It is
further intended to provide an area along highways and major traffic
thoroughfares which has lots large enough to meet the needs of drive-ins and
other highway uses that require large lots and low building coverage, in order
to lessen the friction with surrounding uses and to obtain better business
advertising through grouping. (1990 Code § 12-320)
11-7C-2: PERMITTED USES:
All buildings or uses hereafter established or enlarged shall comply with the
conditions and restrictions provided for in this article:
Amusement establishments, including archery ranges, shooting galleries and
other amusement facilities.
Amusement parks, including permanent carnivals and kiddy parks.
Animal hospitals, kennels, and pounds; provided, that such uses are located not
less than one hundred fifty feet (150') from the boundary line of any
residential district.
Appliance and furniture sales and service.
Auto laundries.
Automotive sales and repair.
Boat showrooms.
Building material offices and sales.
Discount department stores.
Gasoline filling stations.
Golf, driving ranges, "pitch and putt", miniature golf and par 3 courses.
Greenhouses.
Implement sales and service; provided, that all yard requirements shall be
applicable irrespective of conditions stated in this title, and that no outside
sales shall be permitted that encroach upon the yards as established.
Mobile home sales.
Motels and hotels.
Outdoor theaters.
Restaurants, including drive-ins.
Retail stores providing services to and related to highway and travel. (1990
Code § 12-321)
11-7C-3: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:
Minimum lot frontage shall be one hundred feet (100') in the C-3 district.
Other provisions of height, bulk and off street parking in this article shall
govern. (1990 Code § 12-322)
11-7C-4: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
The provisions of height, bulk and off street parking in this article govern.
(1990 Code § 12-323)
11-7C-5: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
There shall be provided a minimum front yard of thirty feet (30') in the C-
3 district. There is no requirement for side yards between and among parcels
within the C-3 district; however, in the event that abutting property has
another commercial or an industrial district classification or a public
dedicated street, there shall be provided a minimum side yard of thirty feet
(30'). In the event the abutting property is residential, the minimum side yard
requirement shall be thirty feet (30') from any solid fencing which shall be
five feet (5') to seven feet (7') in height. (1990 Code § 12-324)
11-7C-6: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: In the C-3 district, no building, sign or structure, or
portion thereof, shall exceed a height of fifty feet (50') from the mean lot
elevation nor will it exceed four (4) stories.
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): In no instance will the total
floor space of the structures in this district exceed the relationship of one
to four (1:4); i.e., there must be provided four (4) square feet of open space
to each one square foot of floor space in the structures. (1990 Code §§ 12-325,
12-326)
11-7C-7: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
In the C-3 district, off street parking and loading requirements are the same
as those in section
11-7B-7 of this title, for the C-2 district. (1990 Code § 12-327)
11-7C-8: SEWER SERVICE:
No structure or use in the C-3 district shall be erected, commenced or allowed
to continue which does not have a connection to the public sewerage system
considered adequate and effective by the health officer. As a basis for making
his decision, the health officer may require such precaution tests as he deems
to be necessary. Such tests are to be made at the expense of the landowner.
(1990 Code § 12-328)
11-7C-9: SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS:
In the C-3 district, the control of signs and billboards are the same as that
in section
11-7A-9 of this title, for the C-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-329)
11-7C-10: ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Screening: The C-3 district shall be permanently screened from
adjoining residential uses by a solid fence, at a minimum height of five feet
(5') and maximum height of seven feet (7'). The planning commission may waive
the requirement for a screening enclosure or screening area if equivalent
screening is provided by topography or other natural conditions.
   B.   Offensive Conditions: Any permitted use in the C-3 district shall not
be noxious or offensive by reason of the emission of odor, dust, smoke, gas,
vibration, noise or other similar causes beyond the property line which
contains the use. (1990 Code § 12-330)
ARTICLE D. C-4 LOCAL AND OFF HIGHWAY BUSINESS DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-7D-1: General Description
11-7D-2: Permitted Uses
11-7D-3: Minimum Lot Size
11-7D-4: Maximum Coverage
11-7D-5: Yard Requirements
11-7D-6: Height And Bulk
11-7D-7: Off Street Parking And Loading
11-7D-8: Sewer Service
11-7D-9: Signs
11-7D-10: Additional Provisions
11-7D-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION:
The purpose of the C-4 local and off highway business district is to provide a
common location which caters mainly to small, low traffic businesses or
offices. It is the intent to group these businesses not only for convenience
purposes but because these type businesses can usually be located near
residences or commercial businesses due to the quiet nature of their business/
operation with low traffic with little or no disruption or effect upon
adjoining properties. It is further intended to provide an area within a few
block(s) of the major highways/traffic areas to meet the needs of office and
other quiet, low traffic type of businesses. (Ord. 719, 10-3-2011)
11-7D-2: PERMITTED USES:
All buildings or uses hereafter established or enlarged shall comply with the
conditions and restrictions provided for in this article:
Barbershops.
Beauty shops.
Dental office.
Dog grooming.
General office.
Home health office.
Investment office.
Law office.
Medical office.
Real estate office.
Surveyor office.
Other small business or office operations that generally have low traffic, that
maintain open hours that do not generally exceed eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to
six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and that operate in a quiet manner that will not
disturb residences that may be in close proximity to such establishments. (Ord.
719, 10-3-2011)
11-7D-3: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:
Minimum lot frontage (width) shall be fifty feet (50') and one hundred feet
(100') depth in the C-4 district. Other provisions of height, bulk and off
street parking in this article shall govern. (Ord. 719, 10-3-2011)
11-7D-4: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
The provisions of height, bulk and off street parking in this article govern.
(Ord. 719, 10-3-2011)
11-7D-5: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
There shall be provided a minimum front yard of twenty five feet (25') in the
C-4 district. There is a minimum requirement for side yards of five feet (5')
between the building and property line within the C-4 district. In the event
the abutting property is residential, the minimum side yard requirement shall
be five feet (5') from any solid fencing which shall be five feet to seven feet
(5' - 7') in height. (Ord. 719, 10-3-2011)
11-7D-6: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: In the C-4 district, no building, sign or structure, or
portion thereof, shall exceed a height of forty feet (40') from the mean lot
elevation nor will it exceed three (3) stories.
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): In no instance will the total
floor space of the structures in this district exceed the relationship of one
to two (1:2); i.e., there must be provided two (2) square feet of open space to
each one square foot of floor space in the structures. (Ord. 719, 10-3-2011;
amd. Ord. 824, 12-4-2023)
11-7D-7: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
All uses shall provide off street parking with ingress and egress designed so
as to minimize traffic congestion, at the rate of one space for each four
hundred (400) square feet of floor space used. In addition, there shall be
provided two (2) spaces for each three (3) employees or fraction thereof of off
street parking for company owned vehicles. This off street parking restriction
may be altered by the planning commission in individual instances where the
applicant can prove that his operation will in no way interfere with the
parking needs of other authorized uses in the district, nor will his operation
create a congestion of traffic on the street. (Ord. 719, 10-3-2011)
11-7D-8: SEWER SERVICE:
No structure or use in the C-4 district shall be erected, commenced or allowed
to continue which does not have a connection to the public sewerage system
considered adequate and effective by the health officer. As a basis for making
his decision, the health officer may require such precaution tests as he deems
to be necessary. Such tests are to be made at the expense of the landowner.
(Ord. 719, 10-3-2011)
11-7D-9: SIGNS:
Signs in the C-4 district shall be erected upon private property and shall not
encroach upon any public street or walk, except as provided by the applicable
codes of the city, and then no sign shall exceed a height of four feet (4') and
a width of six feet (6'). No electronic signs are allowed in the C-4 district,
with the exception of those required by applicable safety codes, if any. The
lighting of any sign in the C-4 district shall be limited to small, low level,
indirect lighting that will not be bright enough to affect any adjoining
residential property. (Ord. 719, 10-3-2011)
11-7D-10: ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Screening: The C-4 district shall be permanently screened from
adjoining residential uses by a solid fence, at a minimum height of five feet
(5') and maximum height of seven feet (7'). The planning commission may waive
the requirement for a screening enclosure or screening area if equivalent
screening is provided by topography or other natural conditions.
   B.   Offensive Conditions: Any permitted use in the C-4 district shall not
be noxious or offensive by reason of the emission of odor, dust, smoke, gas,
vibration, noise or other similar causes beyond the property line which
contains the use. (Ord. 719, 10-3-2011)
CHAPTER 8
INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS
ARTICLE A. I-1 LIGHT INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-8A-1: General Description
11-8A-2: District Standards
11-8A-3: Permitted Uses
11-8A-4: Minimum Lot Size
11-8A-5: Maximum Coverage
11-8A-6: Yard Requirements
11-8A-7: Height And Bulk
11-8A-8: Off Street Parking And Loading
11-8A-9: Sewer Service
11-8A-10: Signs And Billboards
11-8A-11: Screening
11-8A-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION:
The purpose of the I-1 light industrial district is to provide a location for
industries which do not by their nature create nuisances. The intent is to
preserve this land for industry in the location beneficial to industries and to
prohibit nonindustrial uses. Because of the traffic generated and other
objectional influences created in this district, it is necessary to provide a
buffer or setback area between this district and any other zoning district,
except I-2. (1990 Code § 12-340)
11-8A-2: DISTRICT STANDARDS:
Any use constructed, established, altered or enlarged in the I-1 light
industrial district after the effective date of this title shall be so operated
as to comply with the following standards. No use already established on the
effective date of this title shall be so altered or modified as to conflict
with, or further conflict with, the applicable standards established
hereinafter for the I-1 light industrial district:
   A.   Residential Use: No building shall be used for residential purposes,
except that a watchman may reside on the premises.
   B.   Retail Sales Or Services: No retail sales or services shall be
permitted, except as incidental to, or accessory to, a permitted use.
   C.   Operation And Storage Within Building; Exceptions: All operations,
activities and storage (but not including off street parking and loading of
motor vehicles in operating condition) shall be conducted and maintained wholly
inside buildings, except that storage may be maintained outside a building if
no part of the storage is less than fifteen feet (15') from any lot line of the
tract on which the use is located, and provided any such storage area is
screened from other property (except property located in an I-2 district), with
a decorative fence or planting.
   D.   Noise: No noise from any operation conducted on the premises, other
than that emanating from vehicular traffic, either continuous or intermittent,
shall be detectable at any boundary line of the I-1 district.
   E.   Smoke, Particulate Matter: No toxic matter, noxious matter, smoke, gas,
or odorous or particulate matter shall be emitted that is detectable beyond the
lot lines of the zoning lot on which the use is located.
   F.   Vibration: No vibrations shall be detectable beyond the lot lines of
the zoning lot on which the use is located.
   G.   Exterior Lighting Fixtures: Exterior lighting fixtures shall be shaded
wherever necessary to avoid casting direct light upon property located in any
residence district or upon any public street or part thereof.
   H.   Fuel, Energy: No fuel or energy, except electricity or gas shall be
used.
   I.   Raw Materials: No raw materials shall be processed into any of the
following basic products.
      1.   Metals of any kind;
      2.   Glass;
      3.   Plastic;
      4.   Textiles;
      5.   Leather; or
      6.   Paper.
   J.   Walkways And Grounds: All premises shall be furnished with all weather
hard surfaced walks, and, except for parking areas, the grounds shall be
planted and landscaped.
   K.   Storage Or Use Of Chemicals: Storage or use of chemicals, either solid,
liquid or gas, shall be permitted subject to the following conditions:
      1.   Storage, utilization or manufacture of materials or products ranging
from incombustible to moderate burning is permitted;
      2.   The storage, utilization or manufacture of materials or products
ranging from free to active burning is permitted, provided the materials or
products are stored, utilized, or manufactured within a completely enclosed
building that has incombustible exterior walls and is protected throughout by
an automatic fire extinguishing system; and
      3.   The manufacture of flammable materials which produce explosive
vapors or gases is prohibited.
   L.   Glare Or Heat: Any operation that produces intense glare or heat shall
be performed within a completely enclosed building, and exposed sources of
light shall be screened so as not to be detectable at the lot lines of the
zoning lot. (1990 Code § 12-341)
11-8A-3: PERMITTED USES:
   A.   Uses Listed: All buildings or uses hereafter established or enlarged
shall comply with the conditions and restrictions provided for in this article:
      1.   Building materials sales.
      2.   Commercial radio and television transmitting antenna towers and
other electronic equipment requiring outdoor towers, including antenna towers
for the dispatching of private messages.
      3.   Compounding, processing and blending chemical products, but not
including any materials which decompose by detonation.
      4.   General and administrative offices.
      5.   Machine shops and metal products manufacture and tool and die shops,
provided they do not include any of the following equipment:
         a.   Automatic screw machines;
         b.   Drop forges; or
         c.   Riveting machines;
      6.   Mail order houses.
      7.   Manufacturing and assembling (or any combination of such process)
products from:
         a.   Cork;
         b.   Felt;
         c.   Fur;
         d.   Glass;
         e.   Leather;
         f.   Plastic;
         g.   Wood; and
         h.   Other textiles;
but not including, as a principal operation, the processing of any raw
materials.
      8.   Manufacturing and assembling electrical and electronic products and
equipment.
      9.   Printing and binding plants.
      10.   Public utility distribution centers.
      11.   Research laboratories.
      12.   Warehouses and storage facilities.
      13.   Water filtration plants, pumping stations, reservoirs and lift
stations.
   B.   Manufacturing Processes Or Establishments: Any other manufacturing
process or establishment which can and shall be operated in compliance with the
standards of section
11-8A-2 of this article.
   C.   Accessory Uses: Accessory uses incidental to, and on the same zoning
lot as, a principal use. (1990 Code § 12-342)
11-8A-4: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:
All lots in this district shall be at least one hundred feet (100') in width.
Other provisions of height, bulk and off street parking in this article shall
govern. (1990 Code § 12-343)
11-8A-5: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
The provisions of yard requirements, bulk and off street parking and loading
govern in this instance. (1990 Code § 12-344)
11-8A-6: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Front: There shall be provided a minimum front yard of thirty feet
(30') in the I-1 district.
   B.   Side: The requirement for side yards is a total of thirty feet (30')
between and among parcels within the I-1 district, with a minimum of fifteen
feet (15') on either side.
   C.   Rear: The minimum requirements for rear yard is thirty feet (30').
   D.   Abutting Property:
      1.   In the event that abutting property is other than an industrial
district, but not residential, the distance from the property line to any
building must be thirty feet (30').
      2.   In the event the abutting property is residential, the distance from
the property line to any building must be fifty feet (50'). (1990 Code § 12-
345)
11-8A-7: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: In the I-1 district, no building, sign or structure, or
portion thereof, except smoke stacks and antennas, shall exceed a height of
fifty feet (50') nor will it exceed four (4) stories. (1990 Code § 12-346)
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): In the I-1 district, bulk
limitations are governed by height limits and yard requirements as provided in
this article. (1990 Code § 12-347)
11-8A-8: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
   A.   Parking And Loading Space Requirements:
      1.   In the I-1 industrial district, there shall be provided a minimum of
three hundred (300) square feet of land dedicated to parking and maneuvering of
vehicles for each employee on the main or first shift.
      2.   There must also be provided adequate storage space for all company
owned vehicles on the premises.
      3.   In addition, there shall be provided off street loading spaces in
the following relationship to building square foot as follows:
 
Gross Floor Area In Square Feet Off Street Loading Spaces
0 -- 9,999                      1
10,000 -- 39,999                2
40,000 -- 100,000               3
Each additional 100,000         1 additional
 
   B.   Location And Screening:
      1.   All required loading spaces or berths shall be located on the same
zoning lot as the use served.
      2.   All motor vehicle loading berths which abut or are adjacent to a
residence district shall be completely screened therefrom by building walls, or
a uniformly painted solid fence, wall, or door, or any combination thereof, not
less than five feet (5') nor more than eight feet (8') in height.
      3.   No permitted or required loading space or berth shall be located
within forty feet (40') of the nearest point of intersection of any two (2)
streets or highways.
      4.   No loading space or berth shall be located in a required front or
side yard, and any loading space or berth located in a required yard shall be
open to the sky.
   C.   Size Of Loading Space: Unless otherwise specified, a required off
street loading space or berth shall be ten feet (10') in width by at least
twenty five feet (25') in length, exclusive of aisle and maneuvering space, and
shall have a vertical clearance of at least fourteen feet (14').
   D.   Vehicular Access: Each required off street loading space or berth shall
be designated with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street, highway
or alley in a manner which will least interfere with traffic movement. (1990
Code § 12-348)
11-8A-9: SEWER SERVICE:
No structures or use in the I-1 district shall be erected, commenced or allowed
to continue which does not have a connection to the public sewerage system
considered adequate and effective by the health officer. As a basis for making
his decision, the health officer may require such precaution tests as he deems
to be necessary. Such tests are to be made at the expense of the landowner.
(1990 Code § 12-349)
11-8A-10: SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS:
In the I-1 district, the use of signs and billboards is the same as that in
section
11-7A-9 of this article, for the C-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-350)
11-8A-11: SCREENING:
   A.   Requirement: In the event that an I-1 district abuts a residential
district, there must be provided screening by a fence or wall, a minimum height
of five feet (5') and maximum height of seven feet (7').
   B.   Waiver: The planning commission may waive the requirement for screening
if equivalent screening is provided by topography or other natural conditions.
(1990 Code § 12-351)
ARTICLE B. I-2 HEAVY INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-8B-1: General Description
11-8B-2: District Standards
11-8B-3: Permitted Uses
11-8B-4: Minimum Lot Size
11-8B-5: Maximum Coverage
11-8B-6: Yard Requirements
11-8B-7: Height And Bulk
11-8B-8: Off Street Parking And Loading
11-8B-9: Sewer Service
11-8B-10: Signs And Billboards
11-8B-11: Screening
11-8B-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION:
The purpose of the I-2 heavy industrial district is to provide a location for
industries which may, by their nature, create nuisances, but which do not
create noxious nuisances or are a hazard to the surrounding areas. The intent
is to preserve this land especially for industry in locations with access to
major streets as designated on the major street plan as well as locations
generally accessible to railroad transportation. Because of the nuisances or
other objectional influences that may be created in this district, it is
necessary to provide a buffer or setback strip between this district and other
zoning districts, except I-1. Even though this district caters to industries
which may create a substantial nuisance, it does not permit industries that, by
the nature of their operation, emit odors, gases, dust, noise, smoke, heat,
glare, or vibration in sufficient quantities so as to constitute a hazard to
public health, safety and general welfare. (1990 Code § 12-360)
11-8B-2: DISTRICT STANDARDS:
Any use constructed, established, altered or enlarged in the I-2 heavy
industrial district after the effective date of this title shall be so operated
as to comply with the following standards. No use already established on the
effective date of this title shall be so altered or modified as to conflict
with, or further conflict with, the applicable standards established
hereinafter for the I-2 heavy industrial district:
   A.   Residential Use: No building shall be used for residential purposes,
except that a watchman may reside on the premises.
   B.   Retail Sales Or Services: No retail sales or services shall be
permitted, except as incidental to, or accessory to, a permitted use.
   C.   Operation And Storage Within Building; Exceptions: No storage,
manufacture or assembly of goods shall be conducted outside of a building
unless the nearest point of the activity is more than two hundred feet (200')
from the boundary of any use district.
   D.   Exterior Lighting Fixtures: Exterior lighting fixtures shall be shaded
wherever necessary to avoid casting direct light upon property located in any
residence district.
   E.   Noise, Air Pollution; Offensive Conditions: All manufacturing,
fabricating, assembly, disassembly, repairing, storing, cleaning, servicing,
and testing of goods, wares and merchandise shall be carried on in such a
manner as not to be injurious or offensive by reason of the emission or
creation of noise, vibration, smoke, dust or other particulate matter, toxic or
noxious matter, odorous, glare or heat, fire or explosive hazards.
   F.   Detonation: No activities involving storage, utilization, or
manufacture of materials or products which decompose by detonation shall be
permitted. (1990 Code § 12-361)
11-8B-3: PERMITTED USES:
   A.   Uses Listed: All buildings or uses hereafter established or enlarged
shall comply with the conditions and restrictions provided for in this article:
      1.   Any use permitted in the I-1 light industrial district.
      2.   Blacksmiths, tinsmiths and sheet metal shops.
      3.   Bottling works.
      4.   Canning or preserving factories.
      5.   Coal storage plants.
      6.   Ice cream production and distribution.
      7.   Machinery rental, sales and service.
      8.   Machine shops.
      9.   The following:
Assembling;
Cleaning;
Fabricating;
Manufacturing;
Repairing;
Storing; or
Testing,
Any of the following materials, goods or merchandise:
Apparel;
Beverages (nonalcoholic), processing and bottling;
Building materials specialties;
Clothing;
Compounding and packaging of chemicals;
Cosmetics and toiletries;
Dairy products;
Drugs and pharmaceutical products;
Electrical and acoustic products and components;
Food products (except fish, sauerkraut, vinegar and yeast);
Furniture;
Glass products;
Ice, dry and natural;
Jewelry;
Medical laboratory supplies, equipment and specialties;
Metal products and utensils;
Musical instruments;
Optical goods;
Paper products, including boxes and containers;
Radio, phonograph recorder and television sets and parts;
Textiles;
Toys and children's vehicles;
Trailers and carts; and
Wood products, including wooden boxes and containers.
      10.   Milk, bottling and distribution.
      11.   Monumental stone cutting.
      12.   Motor freight terminals.
      13.   Pattern shops.
      14.   Printing plants.
      15.   Soldering and welding shops.
      16.   Sign painting.
      17.   Railroad yards and switching areas, including lodging and sleeping
facilities for transit railroad labor.
   B.   Special Uses: Any special use which is permitted in the I-1 light
industrial district may be permitted in the I-2 heavy industrial district, and
in addition, the following special uses:
      1.   Spray painting and mixing, but only if the fire chief has certified
that there has been compliance with all fire laws.
      2.   Bulk fuel sales and storage.
      3.   Automobile wrecking and junkyards, provided they are enclosed
throughout the entire perimeter by a solid fence not less than eight feet (8')
in height.
      4.   Processing of meat and vegetable products, including the slaughter
of animals. (1990 Code § 12-362)
11-8B-4: MINIMUM LOT SIZE:
There are no requirements for minimum lot size in the I-2 district; however,
any lot in this district must be at least one hundred feet (100') in width.
(1990 Code § 12-363)
11-8B-5: MAXIMUM COVERAGE:
There are no requirements for maximum coverage in the I-2 district. The
provisions for yard requirements, bulk and off street parking and loading as
provided in this article shall govern in this instance. (1990 Code § 12-364)
11-8B-6: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
Yard requirements in the I-2 district are the same as those in section
11-8A-6 of this title, for the I-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-365)
11-8B-7: HEIGHT AND BULK:
   A.   Height Limit: In the I-2 district, no building, sign or structure, or
portion thereof, except smoke stacks and antennas, shall exceed a height of
fifty feet (50') nor will it exceed four (4) stories. (1990 Code § 12-366)
   B.   Bulk Limitations (Floor Area Ratio): In the I-2 district, bulk
limitations are governed by height limits and yard requirements as provided in
this article. (1990 Code § 12-367)
11-8B-8: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
In the I-1 district, off street parking and loading requirements are the same
as those in section
11-8A-8 of this title, for the I-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-368)
11-8B-9: SEWER SERVICE:
No structure or use in the I-2 district shall be erected, commenced or allowed
to continue which does not have a connection to the public sewerage system
considered adequate and effective by the health officer. As a basis for making
his decision, the health officer may require such precaution tests as he deems
to be necessary. Such tests are to be made at the expense of the landowner.
(1990 Code § 12-369)
11-8B-10: SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS:
In the I-2 district, the control of signs and billboards are the same as that
in section
11-7A-9 of this title, for the C-1 district. (1990 Code § 12-370)
11-8B-11: SCREENING:
   A.   Requirement: In the event that an I-2 district abuts a residential
district, there must be provided screening by a fence or wall, a minimum height
of five feet (5') and maximum height of seven feet (7').
   B.   Waiver: The planning commission may waive the requirement for screening
if equivalent screening is provided by topography or other natural conditions.
(1990 Code § 12-371)
CHAPTER 9
A-1 AGRICULTURAL RESIDENCE DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-9-1: General Description
11-9-2: Permitted Uses
11-9-3: Special Uses
11-9-4: Lot Size And Width
11-9-5: Yard Requirements
11-9-6: Building Bulk Limitations
11-9-1: GENERAL DESCRIPTION:
The A-1 district is established to provide for the use of land for residential
purposes in a predominantly agricultural area. It further intends to retain the
agricultural characteristics and density by requiring large lot areas and low
land coverage until the areas can be feasibly developed and tied to logical
urban growth with adequate safeguards of the public regarding health, safety
and general welfare. It also is the purpose of this article to prohibit
commercial and industrial use or any other use that would interfere with the
continuation of predominantly agricultural uses. (1990 Code § 12-380)
11-9-2: PERMITTED USES:
   A.   Uses Listed: No building or use shall hereafter be established or
enlarged within the A-1 agricultural residence district, except a building or
use devoted to one of the following purposes:
"Agriculture", as defined in this title.
Churches and temples.
Elementary schools and high schools.
Golf courses, but not including golf driving ranges, pitch and putt courses or
miniature golf courses.
Parks and forest preserves, operated not for profit.
Single-family dwellings.
Temporary buildings and uses for construction purposes only and not for
dwelling purposes, nor for a period that exceeds the completion of the
construction.
   B.   Accessory Buildings Or Uses: Accessory buildings or uses incidental to
the foregoing principal uses, including "home occupations" as defined in this
title, private garages, guest houses, toll houses, private greenhouses, private
dog kennels and stables, conducted not for profit, roadside stands, and
quarters for persons employed in connection with the residential use of the
premises. (1990 Code § 12-381)
11-9-3: SPECIAL USES:
Special uses in the A-1 district are:
Municipal or community recreation centers.
Police or fire stations.
Public buildings or buildings operated in the public interest by a not for
profit corporation, including art galleries, post offices, libraries or
museums.
Public or not for profit auditoriums, stadiums, arenas, armories or
sanitariums.
Public or private hospitals or sanitariums.
Public or private schools and colleges.
Public utility and service uses, including:
Electric, gas, telegraph, telephone and water transmission metering and
distribution equipment and structures;
Electric substations;
Gas regulator stations;
Microwave relay towers;
Water reservoirs or pumping stations; and
Other similar facilities. (1990 Code § 12-382)
11-9-4: LOT SIZE AND WIDTH:
   A.   Minimum Lot Size: The minimum lot size is one acre. (1990 Code § 12-
383)
   B.   Minimum Lot Width: The minimum lot width is one hundred fifty feet
(150'). (1990 Code § 12-384)
11-9-5: YARD REQUIREMENTS:
Yard requirements are as follows:
   A.   Front: A front yard fifty feet (50') in depth.
   B.   Side: A side yard on each side of the building not less than twenty
five feet (25') in width.
   C.   Rear: A rear yard that is not less than twenty percent (20%) of the lot
depth and in no event less than fifty feet (50') in depth.
   D.   Accessory Buildings: Accessory buildings may be located in a required
side or rear yard, but no such accessory building shall be less than fifteen
feet (15') from any side or rear lot line. (1990 Code § 12-385)
11-9-6: BUILDING BULK LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Height Limit: The maximum building height is forty (40') feet.
   B.   Bulk: No more than thirty percent (30%) of the area of the lot shall be
occupied by a building or a structure with its accessory buildings. (1990 Code
§ 12-386; amd. Ord. 824, 12-4-2023)
CHAPTER 10
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT
SECTION:
11-10-1: Special Zoning Classification
11-10-2: Intent
11-10-3: Effect Of Approval
11-10-4: Criteria For Review And Approval
11-10-5: Site Requirements
11-10-6: Other PUD Requirements
11-10-7: Application And Review Procedures
11-10-8: Development Plan Changes
11-10-9: Freestanding Commercial Building Permits
11-10-10: Designation On Official Zoning Map
11-10-11: Reversion
11-10-12: Time Limitations On Development
11-10-1: SPECIAL ZONING CLASSIFICATION:
The planned unit development (PUD) is a special zoning district category that
provides an alternate approach to conventional land use controls. The PUD may
be used for particular tracts or parcels of land that are under common
ownership and are to be developed as one unit according to a development plan
(as described below). The PUD is subject to special review procedures, and,
once approved by the city council, it becomes a special zoning classification
for the property it represents. (Ord. 612, 8-5-2002)
11-10-2: INTENT:
   A.   It is the intent of the PUD district to:
      1.   Encourage unified design of housing, commercial, industrial areas,
institutional areas, public facilities, open space and recreation areas, and/or
combinations thereof, to provide for integrated developments having harmony of
design and variety of function while maintaining appropriate limitation on the
character and intensity of use, assuring compatibility with adjoining and
proximate properties.
      2.   Permit flexibility within the development to maximize the unique
physical features of the particular site and a pattern of development that
preserves trees, outstanding natural topography, and geologic features, and
prevents soil erosion.
      3.   Provide for a creative approach to the use of land and related
physical development and provide greater flexibility in the design of
buildings, yards, courts, and circulation that would not otherwise be possible
through the strict application of district regulations.
      4.   Encourage efficient use of land and facilities resulting in smaller
networks of utilities and streets and thereby lower housing costs.
      5.   Achieve a continuity of function and design within the development
and to encourage diversified living environments.
      6.   Provide a vehicle for negotiating modifications in standard
development requirements in order to both encourage innovative development and
protect the health, safety, and welfare of the community.
      7.   Maximize the types of environment and living units available to the
public.
   B.   The PUD district is designed to provide for small and large scale
development incorporating a single type or variety of residential and related
nonresidential uses that are planned and developed as a unit. (Ord. 612, 8-5-
2002)
11-10-3: EFFECT OF APPROVAL:
   A.   Zoning Change: Approval of a zoning change to the PUD district adopts
the development plan prepared by the applicant and reviewed as part of the
application. The development plan establishes new and specific requirements for
amount and type of land use, residential densities, development regulations,
and location of specific elements of the development such as open space and
screening.
   B.   PUD Classification: The PUD classification replaces any previous zoning
district classification of the parcel.
   C.   Special Development Regulations: Where there is no provision in the PUD
development plan for special development regulations, the requirements of the
most restrictive conventional zoning district in which a proposed use or a
structure is permitted shall be applied to the development. (Ord. 612, 8-5-
2002)
11-10-4: CRITERIA FOR REVIEW AND APPROVAL:
   A.   Review Process: Because the PUD provides the opportunity for higher
densities, greater design flexibility, mixed land uses, and improved
marketability, the applicant should be prepared to provide amenities and
services that might not be required or possible in a conventional development.
Review and approval of a PUD is, therefore, a process of negotiation between
the city and the applicant to achieve the intents and purposes of these
regulations. The following factors should be specifically included as review
criteria for the evaluation of a PUD application. Other factors not listed
herein may also be considered in the review process in order to respond to
specific design and land use proposals.
   B.   Design Standards:
      1.   The proposed PUD shall be designed to provide for the unified
development of the area in accordance with the spirit and purpose of the land
uses and zoning districts adjacent to it.
      2.   Design of the PUD may provide for modification of conventional
zoning ordinance requirements for such elements as yard areas, densities,
setback and height on individual lots in accordance with the PUD development
plan.
      3.   Density, land use, and intensity of use requirements shall be based
on the PUD development plan and shall be reviewed carefully to ensure the
general health, welfare, and safety of the community.
      4.   Building code requirements shall not be reduced.
      5.   The maximum number of dwelling units within a PUD shall be based on
calculation of gross density. Gross density shall be established in the PUD
development plan and shall be calculated by dividing the total land area to be
developed for residential uses (exclusive of arterial streets) by the number of
dwelling units.
      6.   Location and type of housing shall be established in a general
pattern and shown on the development plan map. (Ord. 612, 8-5-2002)
11-10-5: SITE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Location Requirements: A PUD shall be permitted in any district except
A agricultural district.
   B.   Minimum Site Size Requirements: There is no required minimum size of
the site upon which a PUD shall be located.
   C.   Off Street Parking Requirements: The off street parking requirements
set forth in this code may be complied with by providing one or more permanent,
common, off street parking facilities for all uses within the development;
provided, that the facility contains the requisite number of spaces for each
use, and that the spaces provided for permanent residents shall be clearly
designated and separated from spaces for employees, customers and service. The
total spaces provided shall not be less than the sum of the individual
requirements and the spaces required for each use, and shall be under ownership
and permanent control of the owners of the use for which the spaces are
required. (Ord. 612, 8-5-2002)
11-10-6: OTHER PUD REQUIREMENTS:
The following requirements shall be met by any proposed PUD:
   A.   Open Spaces: The maintenance and perpetual existence of required
private open spaces, easements and rights of way shall be guaranteed by
creation of entries and the imposition of real conditions, covenants, and
restrictions as required by the city council. A home association shall be
created if a trust or other satisfactory arrangements have not been made for
improving, operating, and maintaining common facilities including streets,
drives, services, and parking areas, and recreation areas.
   B.   Lots Sold For Construction Purposes: When individual lots that are not
a part of an approved and platted subdivision are to be sold for the purpose of
construction, a new subdivision plat shall be submitted, approved, and filed
with LeFlore County prior to the sale of lots and granting of any building
permit.
